reviewText: I've heard that Homefront was the most over-advertised and under-purchased games of its time and that's probably true. It has some brilliant cinematography moments, a solid shooting engine, good storyline, and decent voice acting. I enjoyed every minute I spent playing it and will probably return to do another playthrough later. Good game.
voteText: 210 of 238 people (88%) found this review helpful 11 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Homefront is an FPS which tells the story of a resistance movement fighting back against a near future Korean occupation of the USA.

The game play is a very generic FPS. Pretty much identical to Call of Duty and Medal of Honor; you can only carry two weapons,  and four grenades. You will have to swap to different weapons from dead enemies throughout each level as finding ammo is more difficult than you would imagine. None of the enemies use the same weapon...

Graphics wise, it looks nice, but you can tell the game was released in 2011, it looks better than most games released, however it shows it's age when comparing it to more recent titles. The graphical options are wide and you can probably play this game on a potato if you really wanted.

All the maps in the single player are very well designed, sadly you can't really explore because you are constantly reminded to keep following your squad leader. You fight through various different environments such as the streets of suburbs, department stores, and baseball fields, all of which show a disturbing outcome of the quite scary what if?" scenario from a Korean invasion.

The single player of Homefront will take about five hours to complete; this is pretty short in my opinion
date: and the game ends on a massive cliff hanger
recommended: I would of liked to have seen another two or three more missions to tire up the loose ends in the story.  Multiplayer is still very much alive in Homefront
hoursPlayed: I have only played in a couple of games but I had no problem finding a map full of people to jump into. A lot of the reviews you will read on here will say multiplayer is the strongest aspect of the game
voteText: so they can't all be wrong.\n\nI would like to recommend Homefront; however I would wait till it is on sale

reviewText: Set in the year 2027, Homefront presents a kind of worst case scenario" of the near future. Kim Jong-Il has died and has been succeeded by his son
date: Kim Jong-Un. After unifying North and South Korea
recommended: and forming the Greater Korean Republic
hoursPlayed: Kim Jong-Un begins annexing nearby countries
voteText: such as Japan and Vietnam. At the same time
helpfulPercent: America's economy lies in shambles due to their dependence on foreign oil. After a satellite-launched EMP blast
votesHelpful: Korea finally invades America.In the single player campaign
votesTotal: you play as Robert Jacobs
votesFunny: a former helicopter pilot who is being recruited for "re-education" by the Koreans. But pilots have become scarce in occupied America
commentsCount: and the resistance fighters need one for an important mission. Luckily
column16: it doesn't take them long to liberate you from your Korean captors.The gameplay is fast-paced and exhilarating throughout the campaign. The shooting feels incredibly tight and powerful
column17: and is extremely satisfying. Honestly
column18: I don't remember the last time it felt this good to shoot someone in the face. The AI
column19: for both squad mates and enemies
column20: is outstanding. Your squad mates are able to hold their own in a firefight
column21: and even saved my life on more than one occasion. And your enemies provide a fitting challenge without it feeling like they're cheating. For instance
column22: enemies don't automatically know where you are (like in some shooters) making for some pretty awesome ambush scenarios.As a member of the Resistance
column23: you're almost always outmanned and outgunned
column24: meaning that hit-and-run guerilla tactics are preferred over head-on assaults. And even though you're only a lowly member of the Resistance
column25: you still get some neat toys to play with once and a while
column26: such as the Goliath: a six-wheeled tank-like vehicle that destroys enemies that you mark with a targeting device. You also get to man the gun of a humvee and fly a helicopter over the course of the campaign.The only problem with the campaign is that it is over far too quickly. Consisting of seven missions
column27: it only takes few hours to finish the campaign on normal difficulty.Once you're finished with the campaign
column28: you can always jump into the multiplayer. The online multiplayer in Homefront is almost an exact copy of Call of Duty's online offerings. There are six different classes
column30: that can be customized and renamed. As you gain experience and level up, you unlock new perks and weapons. Up to 32 players can play in a match, and most of the maps are of the suburban variety.Graphically, Homefront is solid. Environments are well-detailed, and help set the tone of an occupied America. Some textures, like the wood grain in a hardwood floor, look absolutely stunning. But shadows sometimes look a little low res, and character models can look sketchy at times. But even if Homefront had the greatest graphics in the world, they would still pale in comparison to the phenomenal sound design. The voice acting is spot-on, and the incredible soundtrack sets the mood perfectly throughout the entire campaign.If you're the kind of gamer that values quality over quantity, then you'll definitely want to check out Homefront.

reviewText:
This satisfies my patriotism fetish more than you can possibly understand.

Nonetheless, it's a somewhat dissappointing game. Much of the story felt as if it could have had real, tear-jerking moments, yet the elements are never explored. I think the largest reason for this is how rushed the game feels.

Don't get me wrong, it plays adequately and looks great. Nonetheless, something about the pacing of the campaign just feels...off. Too much happens too quickly. The protagonist goes from a military grunt nobody who happens to be handy with a gun" to "lord of war who causes the earth to tremble as he breathes in one's general direction" within an in-game week. I had hope for this game. I really did. When I saw a child's parents executed in front of him
date: and when I hid amidst dozens of murdered corpses within a mass grave to hide from communist invaders

voteText: I was wrong.\n\nI'd much rather the game follow a more humble storyline instead of going for huge "emotional" moments and executing them poorly. Your character is a resitance member. Why not have him act as one? Why not have him smuggle objects

reviewText: A decent title game a campaign that doesn't meet expectations, but with a great and unique multiplayer mode.\nHomefront is certainly one of the most unique shooters I’ve ever played, driven by an ingenious and surprisingly well-fleshed out plot and a dark and dreary, realistic setting. But it also controls and feels like a typical shooter, looks like a game that’s several years old, and most importantly, has an inexcusably brief campaign. Multiplayer is Homefront’s redeeming quality, and those gamers out there who are like me and swoon for alternate/future history settings should certainly look into it. However, if what you’re seeking is an upper-echelon shooter, keep looking, because Homefront isn’t what you’re searching for.

reviewText:
Home is where the game is
Let's start of by saying what I need to say about Homefront. Homefront is an unbalanced and a bit rough game that feels unfinished. And that's the main problem me, and many, others had with this game. It sounds a bit silly recommending a game after starting the review with negative things. Why would I recommend this game then? Why should you buy this game then?

The first thing that comes to my mind about Homefront is an abandoned puppy, left with no food, no shelter and left alone in a calm understanding of failure in it's head. You can still see the hope, the brief moment of love it got in it's eyes. If you can open your heart to the sad and helpless Homefront you are treated with a pretty mediocre yet fun FPS experience.

Homefront does a lot of things wrong. But at the same time Homefront does things right. Well, mostly a thing or two. Homefront is a really really mediocre game. It doesn't have any magnificient plot. It doesn't have original, revolutionary gameplay mechanics. But it does have style. And that's enough to cover the worse things with the game behind a well designed and stylized environment.

Homefront deserves a spot of some sort among the FPS genre. It's nothing great. And part of it may be in the way developers treated the game. You can see the partial laziness and the lack of trust on their product made them lose interest in the game and went with the basic idea of every FPS game nowadays; Let's make another one of these" was their motivation to even make Homefront.

Homefront is certainly worth buying if you are in need of a short yet stylized single-player FPS game. Even with it's mediocre gameplay it still manages to entertain for hours with it's challenging Achievements.

reviewText: The positives of this game are that I enjoyed the environment and the way it looks. The weapons especially looked very pretty. I particularly enjoyed the setting of the last chapter. Unfortunately, that's about as good as it got. From start to finish, the single player campaign is a whopping 4.5hrs.  The weapons that are dotted around the environment are quite hard to spot. There's no subtle highlighting or anything. The only time I knew there was a weapon was because I happened to have walked over it, bringing up the option to switch to it.\n\nIt's quite linear in the way that it plays, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, but I didn't enjoy it in this game. The storyline is okay, but nothing compelling. The overall feeling of the gameplay just felt awkward. All in all, definitely not a game to purchase at full price and even discounted it, I'd be wary.

reviewText:
(I’m not a huge fan of first person shooter games in general so keep that in mind when reading this review)
Okay, first off, this game is WAY too short. The campaign took me only 4 hours to complete on normal difficulty (even with me dying and re-spawning every few minutes)  If you are going to charge $20 for a game, make it a bit longer than 4 hours.
Despite having a short campaign, I had a lot of fun playing this game.  It has a wide variety of fun to use assault rifles, submachine guns, sniper rifles, and not to mention goliath-the resistances armored vehicle that you control with a targeter.
The graphics are sub-par even for a game made in 2011.  On many cases I had to lean closer to my monitor to see if it was an enemy I was aiming at or just a stray piece of garbage.
I have nothing to say about the multiplayer mode as I have not played it but I might update my review after I have played it.
Regardless of the short story and the lacking visuals, I enjoyed this game, but I wouldn’t buy it until it goes on sale or the price goes down.  However if you are looking for a fun first person shooter game that won’t kill your computer, Homefront is a very good option
I give this game a respectable 7/10.

reviewText:
Let me first try to explain why it was that I wanted to play Homefront.  Firstly it was the first game that I could remember that brought the fight to American soil and wasn't based on factual past battles or wars.  Here was a new idea, a new war as it were, and it was America defending its land.  Rather than America attacking on someone else’s, which is all too often the case.  The second reason was that the story they chose seems almost feasible.  The “Future History” trailer that was released told a great story that felt like it could happen.  It was a great mix of a new idea in uncharted territory with a hint of possibility.

The first thing that I noticed was the graphics, they were gorgeous.  I spend so much time playing older games that I am, for all intents and purposes, a few years behind on the graphics.  This games not that much different since its already a year and a half old.  The game started with my being taken from my home and placed on a bus to an unknown destination.  The drive down the street was eye opening to the world I had entered.  It was some time after the Korean occupation and everything was about what you would expect.  There were some moments that I thought were funny, and others that I knew were there just for my shock value.

It was shortly after that moment that I had fully removed the rose tinted glasses.  I came back to the game the next day, after playing for about a hour the previous night.  This time all bets were off and everything was on the table.

Cut to four hours later as I watched the ending credits scroll up my screen using all of my will not to drop a huge F-bomb in front of my child.

Terrible, simply horrid and a waste of my time.  I have so many other games I could have spent that time with.  And to have the single player of a game that originally was retailing at $49.99 is ridiculous.  Even its current price of $9.99 seems a bit much for the size of its single player.  It took me longer to beat the first Portal that it did Homefront.

Nothing about Homefront stands out above the crowd, hell nothing about it outside its story is unique in any way.  I remember reading once that Homefront was inspired by Half-Life 2, and its guerrilla warfare.  Its clear that it was simply a handful of moments in the later moments of the game and nothing else from Half-Life 2.  Especially nothing about its ground breaking story, graphics, anything.  That’s about the same as saying that Bust-a-Move was inspired by Pong.  In other words, they say they are inspired by an already well known great game and hope more people will buy their game.

There was also mention of using real companies and logos in the locations.  It was stated to give it the real feel of these locations.  I guess this is true, but I saw it more as; “Lets stick some advertising into the game to make more money!”

There was a moment where I realized that I hadn’t seen any health, and in fact had no clue how much I had.  There was no HUD element with health nor had I seen any heath packs or med kits, not even a single bottle of pills.  It was after this realization that I noticed that as I would take damage the HUD would kind of darken, and once I took cover and stopped getting hit the screen would normalize.  Ah regenerative healing.  I don’t know how I feel about this, but on first use I’m not a fan.  Maybe its just Homefront, but it seems like it made the game too easy.  The only weapon I was even remotely concerned with was rocket launchers.

{SPOILERS]

The overall story was acceptable, but left much to be desired.  There were parts however that I found annoying and unexplained.  For example there is a level where you have to sneak into this outpost/base thing controlled by a bunch of crazy survivalist.  When we arrive the other members of  my party make mention that they don’t know these people but one member of the party did, but he’s now dead.  The crazy survivalist turn on us, what a surprise, and we have to sneak into the place and steal their helicopter.  Now once this part happens we head to the church to steal the copter.  But how the hell does this Connor ♥♥♥♥♥♥ even know here the church is?  When the level starts he states he’s never been here, and now he knows his way around?  I call bull.

Another thing, again with the great Connor, was at the end of the game.  First we ignore the fact that the US Army let use join them on their attack of the Golden Gate Bridge.  Because I refuse to believe that part.  But then, right before the last climactic moments of battle, this Connor idiot gives a little speech and ORDERS THE SOLDIERS AROUND.  Seriously, this guy is telling the army guys what to do.  By this point I had pretty much given up on the game, but when that happened I knew right then and there.  I knew that once I was done, I wouldn't be playing it again.

To make things worse, the whole game you are being yelled at to do this, do that, go here, shoot him.  Just constantly being told what to do, and that gets real old, real quick.  And maybe coming off a game like Far Cry 2 has me a little skewed in my views/opinions.  But I can’t remember any other FPS that was similar to this.  This game is a rail short of being a rail-shooter.  Its really that poorly made, its really that bad.

The story has no real ending.  And to make things worse, the guy that annoyed the crap out of me since the beginning of the game martyrs himself at the end.  Yea, Connor, that idiot.  I was more than happy to hit him with that air strike, but it was a really stupid moment overall.  Because why would they need a guy on the ground to use a laptop to fire an airstrike from a helicopter doing circles over the bridge target?  Why?

And all the cliches where present in Homefront.  The story was pretty predictable on a few occasions, and at times the sheer number of Korean soldiers was just laughable.  Possibly the worst TF2 trade I’ve ever made, and I seriously doubt that I will ever touch that game again.

reviewText: No way could I recommend this game, especially now. I've played it, I've beaten the single player campaign, and it's the most generic shooter story ever with generic dystopian american underdog setting against North Korea (?!?). There's generic stereotype characters such as voiceless protagonist, and a compassionate rebel vs ruthless rebel dynamic. Even generic grab at your heart string moments. All under a generic, on-rails, brainless 4 hour run and gun play style where all the guns are accurate enough for head shots, so just take a big light machine gun and maybe a weapon of choice as you grind through less than 10 levels worth of enemies, all while you comprehend why they played up that you're a pilot and you only pilot an aircraft for a single level.\n\nI do believe Homefront's single player experience was supposed to be bigger and more dynamic, but clearly development time had butchered the story into what it is today. With multiplayer reportedly dead, I'd hardly see any point to buying this game for it's single player alone.

reviewText:
<!-- Updated Review -->

Initial Thoughts & Observations

I'll begin by acknowledging that the length of this game is very short. I would say that there's about 7 Chapters in the game, and each chapter varies in length.

Gameplay & Mechanics

There is a low amount of complexity to the game overall, and it's fairly linear as to what you can do, and when you can do it. I was constantly finding myself having to wait for NPC_1 or NPC_2 to get to a location before I was able to complete an action. There were situations where I would know where the NPC was going, but because I walked there before the time I was supposed to be there, the NPC would be stuck in an animation where they would never complete the action.

Story & Plot

One are that left a lot to be desired would have to be the story. I wouldn't say the story was bad, but I will say that it would have been connected better. To me, it felt as though you went from one scenario to the next too quick, and without any real explanation to why you are doing this, going there, or meeting them. The story has the ability to be high production, but because of the inability to connect each chapter seemlessly, you don't really understand the story itself, but instead understand the overall premise, which is that you're rebelling against invaders.

Weapons & Customization

There's not many weapons to choose from, I would guess about 12, and you will probably constantly find yourself choosing between 3 of them throughout the game, minus a couple chapters. The struggle that I found myself in a lot was when I would find a weapon I liked a lot, particularly the SCAR, but ammo would be fairly scarce. Now this is not the case in all levels, but seldom did I encount enemies had SCARs versus the other handful of guns in the game, so some chapters force you to pick up a weapon that you might not like. There are different weapon skins that you can see, but it's not something that you get to choose, instead an enemy may have a gun, and when you pick it up, it might have camo, or even a different color. There's a few attachments in the game, such as different scopes to use, as well as magazine sizes, but again that's randomly generated based on what enemy had it.

Graphics & Level Design

Graphically, the game isn't too bad considering when it came out. As far as level design in concerned, I feel the game borrows a lot from games like Call of Duty. It seems very cookie-cutter, but that doesn't mean it's a bad thing. It makes it a very familiar experience, but in it's own unique way. The beginning levels aren't very innovative, but as you progress midway through the game, it does add different varieties of gameplay.

Final Thoughts & Conclusion

This was not a very groundbreaking game, and most people will probably feel the game seemed rushed. Having said that, I still found myself satisfied playing it. It's a FPS, that does exactly that. It's not trying to innovate in any areas, but is very reminescent of older FPS games. I wouldn't say this is a everyday shooter however, I would categorize this more as a casual FPS fore those looking to just play something quick. I would still recommend this game for any who generally loves FPS games, and who's interested in something that doesn't need heavy investment. I wouldn't necessarily pay full price for the game, but if you can find a deal on it, or for a reasonable price, I think it's worth picking up.

<!-- Original Review -->

To start off, I will say that this game is extremely short. As in, you can probably beat it in under 2 hours. Having said that, I enjoyed the game quite a bit. The game isn't too complex like your modern day shooters now, in fact it's really limited to what weapons there are to use, and where you can go. It's extremely linear in the sense that you have to wait for your teammates to finish their action before you can proceed. I would say there's about 12 total guns that you can use, and you really only get to use 3 of them for most of the game. I wouldn't say the story was entirely bad, but it wasn't something that pulled me in. For me, it felt like any other FPS, nothing really groundbreaking, but was satisfying as well. Regardless of it's flaws, I still found myself having a lot of fun progressing through the campaign. I wouldn't say it's a great buy for full price, but if you can find it for reasonably cheap, it's a good game that's quick, and offers fun for those who generally love FPS games.

reviewText:
This game is bad in basically every way you can expect a modern military shooter to be bad, so let's go over the checklist:

1) The game treats you like a ♥♥♥♥♥. You're not allowed to do anything until you're told to, and your three buddies do it first.
Open a door? You're too dumb to work doorknobs, bettermake sure literally everyone goes through the door to make sure it was opened right before you do.
Shoot a gun? Nuh-uh, gotta wait until you're told to.
Wanna be an idiot and screw up the mission on purpose? Nope, they don't even give you the tools to fail in many places. You're forced to succeed. Not that the game is easy...

2) The battles are horrendously frustrating. I don't think I've ever played an FPS with a lower TTK, but you don't have the tools necessary to handle this low TTK. Your movement is some of the slowest I've ever seen in an FPS, and cover seems almost entirely useless because your hitbox is much larger than you expect. While you may not be able to see over or around a piece of cover, you'll likely be hit from some indeterminate direction and die before you have the time to repopsition.

Every time you fail a battle, you're required to wait through the dialogue preceeding that battle, adding an extra minute or two on to every failure.

3) The game is still buggy, despite ample time to have fixed these issues. Sentry turrets will often get stuck firing in one position, and if that position blocks somewhere you need to go, you have to restart from the checkpoint or die to the stream of bullets, then going back to the checkpoint.

On some less technical and objective levels, the game has weird issues with its themes and setting. It really wants to have its cake and eat it too; they want you to be terrified and disgusted by the horrors of war, but then encourages you to commit these same acts. *SPOILERS* About half way through the game, there's a point where you set off a white phosphorous mortar and one of the friendly NPCs acts horrified about it; the entire game thusfar had set her character up as complaining about everything, so the impact of this comment is hugely undercut and quickly forgotten. As well, the white phosphorous burns the battlefield completely clean, leaving no bodies. It's a weird moment that tries to 'speak out' against weapons that are already war crimes, but then undercuts and erases the aftermath of what you've done and hides the very atrocity that it's trying to preach about.

To top all of that off, it immediately rushes you into another huge firefight where you use your cool" robot AI rocket machine gun car to blow up soldiers by the dozen. It's just bizzare tonal whiplash.

Overall
date: Homefront is a confused game. It's confused as to how a modern military shooter works
recommended: it's confused about what its themes and characters are
hoursPlayed: it's confused as to what is fun.\n\nThe only reason I could recommend playing Homefront is to examine its flaws and ponder on how it got made and released like this."

reviewText:
Invisible walls everywhere - at several points you're only allowed to walk around an object on one side (e.g. at a library, I tried to go to the right of an awning support, close to the wall - no, you're supposed to go left, more out in the open).

Rather unbalanced - extremely easy at some parts, ridiculously hard at others.  About two hours of gameplay - due to getting killed and having to reload, it took me four.  NPCs would soak up entire clips of bullets without taking damage, but then later one got hit and killed by a single bullet during a scripted event - it really destroyed the suspension of disbelief.

Scripted to within an inch of its life - at one point you are forced to talk to every person in a farming community before you are allowed to proceed with the storyline.  They will not let you proceed until you've sat and listened to each person spout their boring dialogue - and there's no way to skip.

reviewText:
Although I tend to be easily exited about games, even if other players do not like them, this isn't the case for Homefront. I did not like this game.

Pros:
- Rianna, one of you team mates, is beautiful
- Nice Setting on the Golden Gate Bridge during the final battle. It seemed to me like the developers kind of wanted to copy the bridge level from Half-Life 2 but failed to get it as epic.
- Multiplayer is still active. I just played a quick game for 20 minutes and there were 19 people in the session. Not bad for a four year old game with moderate reception

Cons:
- very short campaign
- got stuck many times in the middle of the action because I quickly wanted to move out of the line of fire but a chair or a tiny step kept me from moving
- The game didn't start at first. This was related to physX issues. It took me a while to read the forums and experimenting to get the game working. Many players complain about this problem.
- Extremely linear. Usually I do not mind if a game is linear but in this game you may not even crawl under a fence or climb a ladder or open a door before the other players entered first.
- Too much talking. It's OK during the first play through but starts to suck if you replay levels. And you can't skip it.
- Poor voice acting, except for Rianna, at least in German

I do not recommend this game, even on sale.

reviewText: It's quite decent. Not sure why this game gets the bad rap that it often does. The campaign, although a bit on the short side (7 missions, though they are beefy-sized) is very fun and adrenaline-packed. The premise for the story is original, but the progression of it is kind of bland and the characters aren't very interesting, besides a certain war machine you get to wreak some delicious havoc with a few times (if that can constitute a character). The guns are fun to use and sexy as hell. They feel like, say, a mixture of Call of Duty's and Killzone's guns. The multiplayer is very well-done too, but the active servers are a bit on the short side.\n\nOverall, I'd say this game is a little underrated and didn't get the attention it deserved, despite it having a few weakspots. I had to play it on minimum graphics settings and the lowest resolution (800x600) because I had a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ PC, and I still had a great time with it. It's definitely worth at least a rental/borrow.

reviewText: From what I've read, the general consensus on Homefront is that it's just average. After finally getting around to finishing it, I think the reviewers may have sold it a tad short. I mean, I wouldn't call it a masterpiece, but I also found very little wrong with it. I guess the biggest issue is that the single player (which is all I cared about) only took 4-5 hours to finish. So while it definitely wasn't worth the original asking price, now that it's only $20, it may not be a bad investment if you have ever had any interest in playing it. As far as the gameplay goes, it's pretty standard for a modern shooter. Mostly you shoot people (duh), but some levels mix it up with vehicle sections and other types of mechanics. The final level is also pretty epic. What sets Homefront apart from most shooters is the story, the premise being an alternate future where North Korea has occupied the US. All in all, it's a decent, but short game. Perfect for FPS fans to kill time on a rainy afternoon.

reviewText:
A future based FPS with a few neat mechanics that offer a fresh aspect on the battlefield. Think CSGO when you buy guns with currency you've earned through the match. Well this offers a similar system but with Helicopters, Tanks, Supply Drops and more. reviewText: A great multiplayer game that was ahead of its competition at its time of release. Sadly gamers these days prefer to cannibalize franchises until they are rotten to the core, leaving games that come out under the wrong banner, to die in the sidewalk.\nFirst off if you are thinking of buying this for the single player then don't. It's in tune with other war-themed sp campaigns out there: i.e bad. So what makes this game great? Big, detailed maps. Point based perks + killstreaks to ensure balance. Most killstreaks are skill triggered/manual. Vehicles. Guns feel solid, movement is smooth and gunplay is fast. Battle commander mode is a nice twist on regular game modes. You are given all the right tools to battle both camping and vehicle-stomps/ the game is not easy to cheese or grief. Teamwork is on the lukewarm side as you can lone-wolf if you want. All in all if you want a mp game that plays like a CoD-flavored battlefield then there's nothing that beats this at the moment

reviewText: Excellent, awesome, emotional opening sequence. Good campaign. Great graphics. Shooting mechanics work well, but doesn't feel as tight as some other FPS games (though you can adjust sensitivity for ADS seperately from overall sensitivity). I haven't played MP-so no comments on that, (don't know if people even still play), other than its got your typical game modes you'd find in FPS (CTF, Domination, TDM). Campaign is about 2/3 of a Call of Duty campaign, but more original (North Korean invasion instead of Russian ultranationalists as the bad guys for 3+ installments that we see in COD). I was much more invested in the story in this game than almost any other game I've played. The emotional aspect really hits home" (especially if you consider yourself a US patriot).\n\nExcellent game to play in conjunction with watching the Australian movie Tomorrow
date: When the War Began\n\nDEFINITELY BUY IT ON SALE
recommended: & prepare for the next installment of Homefront: The Revolution

reviewText:
This game follows too far in the footsteps of Call of Duty's on-rails action. Too. Far. E.g., Instructed to snipe a buttdong once I have him in my sights, I immediately take the shot: I am detected, the mission is failed and I restart from the nearest checkpoint. I get to the same moment and wait--wait for this stupid flippin' NPC telling me what to do to finish his stupid flippin' sentence so this stupid flippin' game tells me I can take the shot--the same silenced, undetectable shot--without failing the stupid flippin' mission.

Design like this in the shadow of this entire game, nearly beginning to end. The introduction is great, but the gameplay feels like you're kinda floating around in space, struggling to follow NPCs' instructions from one White Castle to next advertisement.

I can't, however, decide if whether or not I regret playing it....

reviewText:
I only played the single player on the game so just a few comments on the game.  Single player is incredibly short but also very fun.  With the backstory to the game there probably could have been a lot more added but even with what little campaing there was it was very enjoyable.

The story was great in my opinion.  Not the typical you are a military super soldier and you go to whatever country and kill a bunch of terrorists.  No you are fighting for the USA that's been invaded by a united North/South Korea.  The story worked for me because of the setting and enviroment that the Devs created.  There was some incredibly gruesome scenes as well a touch of realism as people are going to do what they feel is best for their survival and it wasn't just everyone against the invaders.

Loved the setting and enviroments that you play through in the game.  Some of the areas are semi generic cover based shooting but some of the locations do evoke some sense of feeling in the game whether pity or anger at whats happening.  The only complaint is that as a FPS the areas are very linear and would have been nice to explore some of them a little more freely maybe open up more paths to achieve the goal.

The game also varied the pacing in the levels for the most part as well.  In some levels it was a constant frenzy of action while others were a little slower with small burts of action to break up the tension.  Again it worked for me because if it was just all 100% constant action shooting every enemy you came across it would get bland fast.

Good deal of weapons in the game, mostly automatic weapons, would have been nice to get some more variety in pistol/shotguns or other weapons instead of just from dozens of different assult rifles.  I also liked that there wasn't just a ton of ammo laying around everywhere to collect.  I was switching between a variety of weapons to keep my ammo up as when I'd get a new weapon there wasn't always ammo for it and I'd be on the lookout for me next weapon or playing a little more conservatively to make what ammo I had count.

Only complaint would be that the character model gets caught up on really odd pieces of terrain and you can't tell if you should be able to get past an area or not.  Sometimes there looks to be a path but you get caught on something.

reviewText:
By now, everyone should be aware that Homefront is an extremely short single player game. It's roughly 3-4 hours depending on individual play style. Looking back at both Medal of Honor and Battlefield: Bad Company 2 with 5 hour single player campaigns, this didn't come as a shock to me.

Homefront brings an engaging story, good voice acting, and nice graphics. The gameplay has a similar feel to both Battlefield: Bad Company 2 and Call of Duty 4 games. The shooter aspects definitely feel right. Taking the role of a resistance fighter, your mission is to commandeer jet fuel trucks and deliver them to the army--a tiny mission in a very big war.

The one flaw that annoyed me was the character mouths were out of sync with the voice acting. It gave the impression of a badly dubbed movie. And it's probably best to think of the game as Homefront: Episode 1 due to its length. But armed with that knowledge, I came out of it with an enjoyable experience overall.

You just play follow the leader" for 90% of the campaign. Deviating from the leaders course is unrewarding/pointless

reviewText:
Homefront was a strange experience.

I was huge into Team Fortress 2 at the time and they were giving away a copy of Metro 2033 and a hat for the Soldier class aa a pre-purchase bonus so I figured why not? It turns out I got more mileage out of the Genuine hat than either game I got out of that deal.

One has to look at the media blitz surrounding this game as an indicator that when you have people dress up as the antagonists of the game at gaming conventions and events and releasing hundreds of balloons over the Golden Gate Bridge to promote it you have to wonder if the developer is putting too many of their eggs in the basket. If you can, go look up the review PlayitBogart did of Rise of the Robots to get the gist of what I'm saying.

To the game itself now.

Homefront was not a hot mess; it played just fine and controlled like a modern FPS should despite all the difficulties I had adjusting to the keyboard and mouse after playing shooters on consoles for almost seven years prior. A lot of the high points of the game came in the first half of the campaign showcasing the cruelty of the North Koreans by having things such as piles of dead Americans being buried en masse in a baseball field or a childs parents being shot in right in front of you as you are transported on a bus. They even briefly touched on one of your companions facing racism due to the fact he was half-Korean. Surely some attempts to invoke emotion were expected in a game touching on this subject matter.

...That's about the end of the positives however. Looking back I disliked this game for the lack of content it had and all the glaring flaws in how it tried to do what it did. For starters, all the main characters played out as pure sterotypes which for the purpose of this review I will refer to them as Jarhead, Girl, Target of Racism (TOR), and Father Figure.

You escape from a bus and turn into Dothis McPlotdrive III as you try to meet up with Jarhead's friends to try and fight back against the Koreans who were somehow able to unite almost all of East Asia and occupy an economically crippled United States. Is your immersion broken yet? Don't worry, I was somehow able to care less about the characters in this game by the end of it all. Jarhead and Girl argue constantly as you are led through the war torn suburbs to a hidden oasis where the resistance has set up a self-sufficient hide-a-way led by Father Figure.

You are then led through a night mission where you are bombarded by advertisments for actual real world companies and establishments to the point where you actualy have to fight your way through a Tiger Direct store and pass by a Hooters. I wish I was kidding. This was a design choice by the developers to try and increase the immersion but astute gamers will see this as a disturbing trend where fiction and reality break down. The same thing happened when I noticed real world ads would start appearing on billboards in Saints Row 2; it takes me out of the game and reminds me the crappy real world exists.

You go through American held lands with TOR to do something in the cornfields. I think it was to find a helicopter to escort some fuel trucks for the military to use to fight against the Koreans. The game just spirals down into oblivion after this.

The whole premise of the game is laughable at best anyway. You expect me to believe a small nation that refuses to feed it's populace would just somehow take over it's neighbors and confront the only real Superpower on the planet? Would this make more sense if the antagonists were Chinese as was originally planned? A change that was made because the devs were afraid of a people who are notorious for breaking copyright law like it's nothing and banning anything that portrays their nation in a bad light?

The worst problem I had with this game was the fact it was obvious sequel bait. When you finally get to the climax of the game you expect to confront the main bad guy that they built up all game to, only to be blue-balled by We are finally turning this war around" before the credits roll.

There was no follow-up until recently with Homefront: The Revolution serving as a reboot of the series
date: effectively making this game pointless story wise. But hopefully developers look at it as a lesson of how much high expectations can sink a company. Kaos Studios was shuttered shortly after release and according to Wikipedia shares of THQ declined by almost a quarter
recommended: ultimately leading to the demise of THQ.\n\nMultiplayer was also a strange mix of Battlefield and Counter-strike where you fought in tug of war style battles and earned credits to purchase weapons
voteText: vehicles and the like. In retrospect
helpfulPercent: it wasn't unique enough for me to continue trying to do better. I just went back to TF2 shortly after with my Genuine Hachimaki.\n\nI could only recommend this at a steep discount or as a video playthrough. Aside from that
votesHelpful: you didn't miss much."

reviewText:
Well. Homefront wasn't actually terrible. It wasn't very good either though.

Lets start with the flaws. For starters, the campaign is notably short and can be beaten in about 4 hours, which includes dying a number of times. The plot is basically Call of Duty: Red Dawn, but a lot less military based and a bit more guerilla warfare based. Basically, it's not very unique.

The context is that in 2013, after the Supreme Leader of North Korea dies, his son unites the North and South to form the Greater Korean Republic. This should be the biggest clue that Homefront is purely speculative fiction and not to be taken seriously as that will never happen. The South (South Korea) had seperated from North Korea just as the Korean war started because of the atrocities that were going on. Anyway, fast forward to 2025, the GKP is a world power and has already taken over four other countries and begins their invasion of the USA. Another two years later, it's 2027 and you are Robert Jacobs, a former Marine combat pilot who is awakes in his beat apartment in Montrose, Colorado. The Koreans have seized the town and are sending you to Alaska for re-education". Well
recommended: you're rescued by the resistance and recruited to help fight the good fight. That's pretty much it. There's little development in character or tone
hoursPlayed: it's just very one sided. At least Call of Duty (everything since Modern Warfare)  gave the villains a sort of character to help build up their wrongdoings. You don't even get to know the Koreans
voteText: they're just targets for all of you.\n\nSPOILERS: There is one level where there might be some shift in tone
helpfulPercent: but it ends up being a massive firefight anyway. American survivalists; those nut jobs who like to keep their guns close in case something like this would ever happen
votesHelpful: which won't. It won't ever happen. But people like the people in this game do exist. In one of the missions
votesTotal: these survivalists have a helicopter you need and basically you end up killing them all.\n\nWell
votesFunny: at least the audio design and graphics were nice. The campaign was still fun to play
commentsCount: but it's nothing special. More of thing where you play it just to pass the time and you only own it because it was in a THQ Humble Bundle or it was on sale for like 3 bucks.\n\n7/10"

reviewText:
As an idle diversion this was alright. If you're bored and it's on sale and you just wanna mindlessly destroy enemies, go for it.
If you're going for something for story content, innovative gameplay or a new experience I'd suggest running away as fast as you can.

I bought this title on sale for five dollars US, for five bucks I'd say it was worth it, I enjoyed it *JUST* enough to warrant it. For full price? I'd probably be pretty mad I bought it.

My take on things:

The Story:
The story's background is so impossible you'd be more likely to encounter Santa astride a Unicorn than the scenario depicted in this game.
The characters are tired stereotypes and overacted, sometimes hilarious so.
The writers seemed to really want me to have an emotional response to this game and the events in it. If their goal was annoying me, they succeeded. If the intent was making me feel something for their poorly written characters they utterly failed.
It was also extremely predictable, so many moments meant to be surprising weren't in the slightest.

The Gameplay:
It's a retextured Call of Duty, and it somehow managed to actually be worse than call of duty. This includes the shocking" moments and first-person moments of your character being tossed about and blown around.
It works off the exact same mechanics as Call of Duty
date: enemies endlessly spawn until the player advances to a certain point.\nAll engagements play out almost exactly the same and get exceptionally boring.\nThere's a complete lack of bullet penetration
recommended: shooting at an enemy behind plywood or a plastic traffic pylon results in absolutely nothing.\nI can recall years ago when this game was coming out a trailer touting that "this game will be different" and something close to "we won't have you killing hordes of enemies
hoursPlayed: we want to avoid kill-fatigue in games like Call of Duty where you just kill people on automatic and don't even think about it after a certain point". It was a blatant lie
voteText: I'd be hard pressed to point out a game with more generic enemies packed into small areas than this one.\n\nAt the end of the day I've played worse
helpfulPercent: but not many.\nIf you want a game wherein America is the one getting invaded and you don't mind an RTS I'd highly suggest World in Conflict as a viable and fun alternative. Much better writing
votesHelpful: much more plausible story."

reviewText:
Wow, I'm impressed! Homefront exceeded every expectation I had and then some. So glad I bought it on a whim when it randomly went on sale.

This is the game I can imagine would be born if Half-Life 2 and Spec Ops: The Line had a baby together. If you've played both of those and then you play this I think you'll instantly be able to tell why.

Mechanically, it's pretty much the same as every other shooter. The guns and enemies are pretty standard. The guns themselves have a lot of variety but most of the rifles feel so similar that it doesn't really matter. I found myself choosing which to use more based on which scope was attached than any other attribute. The enemies could have used some more variety and better AI, but in the end the game didn't hinge on either of these things.

What matters is the story and the world they created. It's a distopian future where you sometimes fight alongside a squad of NPCs and a robot companion against a foreign occupying force (that's the Half-Life 2 part). But they did such a good job presenting this world I'm in awe. There are tiny touches everywhere: things happening in the background, banter that's easy to miss, all these really human moments that make the game come alive. Because of that it felt a lot like The Last of Us during the early levels.

Stylistically it's a bit dated even for 2011 game - honestly it looks a lot like Half-Life 2. The models and textures have a pretty flat look to them, and none of the shininess that a lot of games from the era seem to have everywhere. The lighting and depth of field effects are amazing at points though, even if the game were made today. They're subtle but effective. The backgrounds are often pure works of art.

The sound system is crisp and includes great voice acting. The score is epic and memorable and features some hilarious yet appropriate tracks from real life bands.

Overall I loved playing through it twice (once on the highest difficulty and once for collectibles and achievements). I only wish that there were bots for the multiplayer so that I could try it out, as there are literally zero people online nowadays.

I'm psyched that there's a sequel in development. Seriously can't wait to get back into this world. Here's a trailer: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RNtIv_wjc_g

With grand setpieces and an emotional, evocative story, Homefront is not a game to be missed.

reviewText:
I regret even buying this game at $5,

Single player was so overdone, cheesy, tryhard, and generally ♥♥♥♥♥♥ I had to take breaks just to calm my cringe down. Good thing too as the campaign was probably only 3-4 hours long. I guess if you're still stuck in the 00's and enjoy a good direct2DVD or Mockbuster experience then this is your game. Honestly I felt like I could play Modern Warfare 2 and have a more polished experience.

One story, breaching a garage I headshotted every dude inside except two standing by a wall full of explosive barrels. Guess what, even when you flank around them and shoot them the barrels explode. A lot of it was like 'The Best of: FPS scenes' and felt incredibly corperate and marketable. The only comment I had afterwards was how triple A gaming needs to die, like now.

Multiplayer was pretty good though, but since it's so long after release at this point it's just a bunch of guys who got too good and are now circle jerking in their clan servers. Not a bad thing but I don't have the kind of time investment to join up at their skill level.

reviewText:
Ok, so I played this game on console back when it was released, I borrowed it of a mate, completed the campaign, and gave it back.
I thought it was good and worth a play, so when I saw it for <£3 I decided to pick it up on steam.

Now, as I replayed the campaign, I started to remember just how much I enjoyed playing it the first time, and the same can be said for now, despite being a bit short, (Though still think it is longer than most of the Call of Duty campaigns), it is brilliant, dark and rather unsettling at points.

Now one thing I never played before was the multiplayer, and I know people are saying the MP is dead, but they are WRONG.
There is usually only 1 or 2 servers playing, but so what, there are people coming in and out of the servers constantly so there are usually anywhere between 24-36 player online at once, and that is more than enough for me to of played about 6 hours of online in 2 days.
The online has some bad points, such as few weapons, (5 Assault rifles, 2 SMG's, 2 LMG's and 2 Sniper rifles) and low player count. But this is very minor, I have enjoyed playing the MP, using drones and vehicles alongside infantry, and the vehicles are surprisingly well balanced, maybe excluding the helicoptors, but they are aggrivating to pilot which means unless your truely skilled at piloting then your going to struggle getting kills.

The graphics are good, the gameplay is good, the game is great.

I only wish I had bought this when it first came out on Steam, so I could play in different servers with more players.

reviewText: First I have to get this out of the way, the single player game sucks! I think that Kaos put the focus on multi-player and it shows in a brilliant execution.The maps offer something different on every change up, which will entice you to want to change weapon classes as the scenery changes. i.e shotgun in the supermarket aisles or sitting on top of the hoover damn with a sniper rifle. The battlepoint system is a great switch from the popular killstreak system" and offers even mediocre players a chance to take out the big vehicles and airstrikes etc at least once a match if they save the points. The drones add a totally new dimension to the standard FPS format (having to watch the skies as well as the horizon)
date: and the overall feel to game play is absolutely unique .The weapon balancing is perfect (not on all servers) and the vehicle physhics are well done. (again not on all servers weapon balance and expert vehicle control are admin options) Overall this is the best military FPS I've played yet."

reviewText:
Playing this game makes me angry.

Angry that I paid any amount of money for the privilege of suffering through it. Angry that I went to the effort of obtaining it from an American friend when I heard they were (initially) blocking it on Steam in the UK, due to an amazingly stupid deal THQ struck up with high-street game retailers for (initial) exclusitivity. Angry that it's Baby's First Call Of Duty Clone. Angry that its heavy-handed message is either too transparent or lost in the mud. Angry that it's STILL a buggy piece of ♥♥♥♥, with frequent graphical lockups and dialogue going waaaay out of synch with the animations. And finally, angry that I've had to wait until now to warn everyone about this anti-game, once again due to it not existing in the UK Steam Store until the deal expired.

I'm almost disgusted that Valve gave it pride of place in the 4th Of July art for the Steam Summer Camp event. Only CoD fanatics could love this monument to everything wrong with modern 'AAA' FPSes.

reviewText:
I can see why some people were upset - the entire single player missions took me about 3.5 hours.  However I disagree with most reviews on the actual game itself.  I felt like the levels had a really great design, the set peices and artwork were actually very well done.  The varied gameplay within the 3.5 hour game changes a lot and didn't get stale like most 7 hour FPS games get.

Having played the single player Call of Duty games and Battlefield, I actually found this single player missions to be more fun and well done... with the exception of that sneaky mission in Call of Duty 4, that was a great mission.

The downfall is the weak AI (enemy), the story is unbelievable, some areas are too linear and forumla based, and your combat team is OP.  I didn't play the multiplayer but I hear its weak.

Since I got this game in a $5.00 bundle of 4-5 games, I cannot complain at all.  I was entertained and honestly... I am glad it was short and had a bunch of different gameplay.  Helicopter, vehicle, sneaking, sniping, fast action, and the generic UAV, lmao.

reviewText: I picked up Homefront from the $5 bin in Walmart knowing that the game was old and that it didn't receive much praise. I do agree that the story was a bit too short at only about five hours long. I still enjoyed the story based on its premise. With the USA being so high and mighty recently it is nice to see it being a hollow broken shell of itself. The look and feel of the game's atmosphere was very Red Dawn (the original 1980s movie) to me. Most of the characters where one dimensional and shallow but they do their jobs well. The game play is well complaint and works but parts of the game are very hand holding and scripted.  With a sequel on the horizon it will be interesting to see what happens with this well thought out but not quite well executed world.

reviewText:
This game one of most underrated game I play.

Single player campaign is fresh with American empire taken over by missile mad Koreans.  People say campaign too short or not as good as Modern Warfare game.  I don't see problem.  The game has good direction as you move through occupied America watching Korean kick ♥♥♥ before big battle on red bridge.

As well as killing many Korean I also like that you can do some parts where you also kill Americans.  Without this I would not like game as much.  Campaign not hard but good to see story and horror of war, such as Americans thrown into ditch.  Maybe a new Homefront could be made where Jalalabad control America.  This would be true epic and big seller in my country.  More so that pirated copies of Windows XP.

Multiplayer is really really good.  You run, kill, die, respawn... over and over repeat process.  More kills and objective points give you bonuses like unlock vehicles and air strike.  Within few minutes of game you see people bring chopper and tank.  No spawn killing as spawn keep moving away from enemy.

Another thing about online that make me hard is knifing.  You can spam knife running through building to make new Kill Bill 3 movie. reviewText: I love this game. This game is much more personal than many other FPS' out there. It's got the best opening to a game I have seen since Resident Evil 2. Although the campaign is short there are tons of hidden newspapers that are interesting to read and if you're into the story adds a lot building up to the events in the game. They're a lot of fun to read but you they aren't stored anywhere to read later so if you want to read them you have to do it then and there. reviewText:
Experience the disaster that destroyed both a developer and a publisher due to over management, unrealistic expectations and a complete lack of a clear goal.

Experience the inability of opening doors, walking through corridors or climbing ladders unless your teammates do it first.
Experience being unable to take cover because your AI squad takes it first.
Be confused by the lack of ammo, weapons that all look the same until you randomly pick one and realize it's ♥♥♥♥.

See the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ graphics, with low quality textures that for the most part are completly lacking normal maps or any other detail aside from those few lucky ones that were given ♥♥♥♥♥♥ bumps using the Nvidia filter.

And last but not least, have your agonizingly slow pace constantly interrupted by random invisible walls and weird collision detection that will put your adventure to a halt every 5 goddam seconds.

Homefront is where the fiasco is.

reviewText:
Homefront is a fairly incredible game. However, there is one problem I have with it:
The ending, at least in my opinion, is a cliffhanger. It gives you a glimpse of what may be to come, but the entire setting is based on one city in America and it's fight to take back what belongs to them. While I enjoyed the game's story, I felt the ending was lacking. Feel free to tell me I'm wrong if there is anything I missed.

I haven't played the Multiplayer.

Great game, but 8/10.

EDIT:
Okay, so I recently learned that there is going to be a Sequel to Homefront, which makes me understand the Cliffhanger ending a bit more, but it's kinda ballsy to leave the first game on a Cliffhanger with a new franchise. My score remains the same, however.

reviewText:
This game is outstanding, in your face, awesome storytelling with non stop action all the way through. I found myself thoroughly engaged in the world. I had an absolute blast playing it. The online mode is comparable to other online FPS gems like CSGO. There is nothing like standing on top of a white castle sniping people who are running around the Hooters next door.

The story mode took me somewhere between 6 and 8 hours to complete. Surviving and fighting in a world where a country invades America... the scenery is really interesting. The story is compelling. You want to take out the enemy and achive your goals.

I give this game a 10/10.

I would play through the story mode again and I continue to snipe people who hang out at Hooters.

reviewText: The storyline is a bit farfetched, considering that North Korea is not really a global superpower, but it is still very good at portraying what it would be like to live in a country where a hostile take over has occurred. As an FPS it plays very smoothly, and the keyboard controls make the game feel like it was designed for PC despite also being released on consoles. Also, this is the only game I've played where you have to disturbingly hide in a mass grave under corpses to get away from your enemy (although, this only happens once in the game, it was a very profound look into what people will do to survive in times of war).

reviewText: Short, intense game, about 10-12 hours, It felt like there should have been more to it, the end arrives without warning. Sometimes it felt like a shooting gallery game, but it is pretty gorgeous looking and the settings are excellent. Be warned that it is also rather graphic at times - mass graves, families being killed and other horrors of war. The game doesn't pull its punches. No save on demand is annoying, but I'm getting used to the trend and there are enough checkpoints that it's not too annoying except that sometimes the game will change weapons on you when you die. Map design is fairly linear, but the avenues are wide enough to approach situations from various angles and your NPCs will back you up along the way. You may be annoyed occasionally when stuff that it looks like you should be able to climb/jump onto is ... not. That said, these really are minor shortcomings and they should not discourage you from this otherwise excellent FPS war game. I really enjoyed it and it captured my attention enough that I played it to the exclusion of other games until completed. There's definitely potential for a great FPS series here.

reviewText: Homefront is nothing more than a boring but thankfully short shooting gallery.\n\nThe premise of the game is actually quite good and is probably the only saving grace of the game. If you are a fan of Red Dawn than you will be extremely dissapointed as this game has a pretty decent premise but terrible execution. The story is terrible with shallow characters that will leave you with no emotional attatchment at all. Homefront tries to be a serious game but it ultimately fails . Even in its most emotional" moments you really wont feel sorry for anyone. The graphics are extremely dated. Textures look terrible especially on bigger levels and the same 4 North Korean enemies are recycled throughout the game. Your allies also look extremely bad and are usually blank faced or have some ridiculous stare that was meant to show the intensity of the battle but ends up just making the player laugh. The guns are also pretty bad looking and their sounds are god awful. The voice acting is sub par as well. One of the bigger faults of this game is that it is extremely boring. The game basically boils down to killing a mass of enemies before going and pushing a switch or blowing something up. After the task is complete you run around for a bit more and to it again. Homefront is also extremely easy. The game offers no challenge on medium difficulty. I died about 3-4 times during my run of the whole campaign and that was only because I tried to "rambo" it a couple of times. The only ridiculous mechanic that offers even the slightest challenge is the fact that enemies are ♥♥♥♥ing sharpshooters that can hit you from across the map when they see just a sliver of your shoulder. But even with this just proning behind cover every once in a while will do the trick. This game is also extremely short. I finished the 7 chapters of the campaign in a mere 3.4 hours. That is ridiculous and should not be acceptable by any means even if the game has a good story.  Those 3
date:
4 hours were extremel tedious and painfull. By the end of the game you are just relieved that the nightmare is almost over then Homefront decides to give you one last ♥♥♥♥♥slap across the face by sequel baiting and leaving a cliffhanger. ♥♥♥♥ off at least we deserved a proper ending but nooooo. Dont go near this ♥♥♥♥ing awful game.

TLDR: Everything about homefront is terrible and you would get more enjoyment out of a cup of coffee than this game. Its not worth $19.99 and its not even worth $4.99 when its on sale. Dont touch it. Forget about it. Burn it with fire. Please run before its too late.

reviewText:
Let me list the ways you can die in this game.

Grenade that's 10M away from you
Insanely accurate machine gunner from 100M+
RPG Units that know exactly when you're coming up from prone
Following your squad leader
Tanks/APCs with Terminator level guidence systems
Random explosions

Now to the serious stuff, this game is really not good. You are some indiscriminate character drafted into the resistance, after some event happens. I honestly don't remember what it was, as it was that forgetable. And seriously, the North Koreans as an enemy? Could they not find a smaller army?

Homefront suffers from horrible AI, both enemy and friendly. Enemies will stand out in the open, laying down massive and accurate rounds of fire on you. Fire one shot, and they all train their sights on you instantly. Friendlies will get in the way at every single chance. Also, you are forced to be the last person through any entry point. Meaning; have to climb up a ladder? Have fun watching your three squad mates climb up it frirst before you get a prompt to climb. Wanna crawl under that fence? Nope, have to wait till everyone goes before you.

None of the characters are memorable, including the one you play. In fact, there were plenty of times where commands were issued and I had to question if I was the one being commanded to do them.

The story is disjointed at best. A game about the occupation of the US? Cool, I'm in, but this was poorly done and felt rushed. Great potential with the idea, making US citizens insurgents, but more time could have been spent fleshing it out. After 4.5 hours I had the game beat, and that was after I died, a lot.

Speaking of which, the ending, talk about the most lack luster ending ever. Granted I didn't stay past the first couple of credits (I exited quickly to write this review) but there was no gratification, no bad guy to defeat, no nemisis to duel. Just a quick battle for a landmark and roll credits. This could have easily been a trilogy if the time was taken to create a proper story.

At 75% off it's still not worth it. Although I should note that I have not played the multiplayer (And won't) so I can't comment on its value there.

This is a great idea for a game, but horribly executed, painfully short and terribly forgetable.

reviewText:
SINGLEPLAYER

Homefront is an alright game, but I do not recommend it due to the fact that it has more cons than pros. The story is alright. But has quite a few plotholes in it. The first couple minutes though, really shows you some of the depressing things in the world of Homefront and they are actually pretty well done.

The enemy AI is alright but your teammate AI is honestly pretty bad at least from my experience. Graphics are gritty looking and ugly, but the gun models, people other than important characters and dead bodies are weirdly good looking compared to the rest of the game. Especially the guns, seriously, they look REALLY good. Non of the characters are really all that likable and you play as a silent character (Which is a gripe that some people have with certain games. I for one don't mind silent characters if they are properly done, however, in Homefront it adds plotholes. Looking through iron sights is a toggle rather than a hold (You can't change it in settings). There are A LOT of invisible walls. This game is extremely linear. There are invisible walls in places where you would think it makes sense to go. When you're in calm areas where you can interact with people you move at a snails pace. Like, REALLY slow. For the most part the game is boring but it kinda ramps up when you're halfway through the campaign, especially with the last level which in my opinion is the best part of the campaign. When you're in areas with team AI, you have to wait for them to reach the end of the level for you to proceed to another area (It's probably a way that the devs made to load the next level). Also it's really easy for you to die, at least for me (Difficulty is a preference but even on easy the enemy AI were pretty unforgiving).

Oh and the campaign is 4 hours long. Shorter, depending on how you play (I died a lot).

Overall, I don't recommend this game. There are too many cons with this game and not enough pros. I thought almost the entire game was really boring other than the last hour or so. If you want to dive into the world of Homefront you might as well wait for the sequel, Homefront: The Revolution which is an open world game that fixes all the problems I have it this game. But if you want to, get this game when it's on sale.

reviewText:
Wow. Where do I start with this one?

After reading some of the other positive reviews it seems that most people enjoy this game for its multiplayer. I am not really that into multiplayer games and even if I wanted to play multiplayer on this game I doubt there would be very many open servers (I could be wrong).

That aside my review is based solely on the single player campaign and it is for those of you who are considering getting this game for the campaign.
It's not worth it. It's not worth 19.99. Luckily I was able to get my copy from Amazon which was much cheaper but if you were to purchase this on steam I would wait for a sale.
The combat is okay, nothing special, typical FPS really. The enemies and allies alike make the same sounds when being shot, the guy Connor barks at you constantly as if his testicles have been punched into his stomach, and the game gets a little buggy when the NPC's are waiting/expecting you to follow them - when in fact I would be in front of them. Also barking orders after I've already done what they told me to do, just simple sort of bugs like that.

The story.. er.. plot, there isn't really much of one. Which is disappointing because I applaud this FPS unique choice to have a guerilla warfare shooter take place in the USA, but they really dropped the ball with this one. I couldn't care less about any of the characters, in fact I wanted Connor to die. He annoyed the crap out of me.
The story/plot felt so mediocre that they even managed to fulfill the stereotypical Asian engineer/computer technical guy and the black guy that dies halfway through the game. Shocker.

Nah, I'm kind of kidding about that part, I mean yeah, I noticed it was kind of a stereotypical thing but that's not really a big deal to me. It's just it was the cherry on top of an already lackluster sundae.

In a few months I'll probably not even remember a single thing about this game because none of it was memorable. I should have listened to the reviews that said not to get the game if you were just interested in the campaign. Well, reviewers that said that - You were right.
Also the game is kind of short. I know that 8-12 hours is a standard length for a FPS, but I played the game on hard and beat it within 5ish hours. (The almost 10 hours thats recorded on Steam was because I left for several hours with the game paused a couple of times).
If I played the game on easy or normal, I'd imagine one could finish this within 4 or less easily.

Anyway guys, I don't recommend getting this game. It's not worth the price they are asking for it. It would be worth a consider if they were asking maybe 4.99-7.99, but definitely not 19.99

reviewText:
This game felt unfinished. For starters, the campaign is all of 3 hours long. And a large chunk of that 3 hours is you twiddling your thumbs waiting for the next highly scripted segment of gameplay to trigger because you as the player can't do much of anything alone. Despite supposedly being an important key figure in the rebellion (which never gets explained, not that much does), you are led by the hand the entire time and trusted to do nothing on your own. You are treated like an incompetent child. You have zero player agency. You can't even climb a ladder until the game gives you a button prompt. The game literally thinks that you are too stupid to perform even the most basic functions without instruction. I don't mind linear games, but this game is so linear that it makes the Call Of Duty franchise look like a series of expansive open world games with great player freedom. The game also suffers from horrific collision detection problems as well as physX issues, leading to many silly deaths and flat out broken sections of gameplay. The story also makes no sense, has terrible pacing, as you would expect from a 3 hour campaign, and is tonally all over the place. It has it's moments of fun, it isn't all bad, but the good moments are rare and aren’t nearly good enough to compensate for how dull and infuriating the experience is for the other 75% of the time. In all honesty, I wouldn't recommend this game at any price.

Here is my full in-depth review
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2hHzJm1gfPI

reviewText:
As generic as they come, Homefront is a game for lovers of the point-and-shoot variety. The story wants to be as poignant as Spec Ops: The Line. The gameplay wants to be as solid as the Call of Duty series. The visuals want to be like Battlefield 3. Unfortunately, all of those aspects fall incredible short of their ideals.

The voice acting is surprisingly strong, but it completely undermined by the utterly dumb AI. Friendly NPCs block you from cover, exposing you to enemy fire. Enemies are very predictable. Difficulty is only ramped up by adding more enemies to the screen. There are a few shining moments of cinematic brilliance, like when you are first escorted as a prisoner through a typical American suburb taken over by the brutal Korean forces, but all of that great storytelling is destroyed by blocky NPC models and outdated textures.

I can't speak for the multiplayer as I only played the single-player.

I give this game a 4/10. It's not worth the $20 price tag, but if you pick it up from a Humble Bundle or on sale, it might be worth the measly ~4 hours it takes to complete the single-player campaign.

Pros:
Superb Voice Acting
Great Cinematic Moments and Storytelling

Cons:
Outdated Graphics
Clunky Gameplay
Frustrating NPCs
Dumb Enemies

reviewText: I was going to make a list of games less linear than Homefront, but since I started with Bowling
date: I decided that was going to be too long of a list.\n\nThe general rule of the game is that if you didn't get a prompt onscreen to do something, or weren't specifically told to do something by another character, it's not the right thing to do. You don't need to worry about that though, since if it's not exactly what the game just told you to do, it's not going to allow you to do it. Invisible walls are everywhere, and don't ever try to walk ahead of a scripted character or the game will stop until you get back where it told you to be.

reviewText: I wouldn't imagine a game built so strongly around Republican fantasises would be so eager to take away my guns. Awkward weapon changes happen every scene, and the main character can't carry more than 90 rounds for any one rifle, and none of the ammo is compatible with the fancy guns you'll occasionally pick up. The action is mediocre, the plot is perhaps more interesting than I would have guessed. The interaction with NPC squadmates is hamfisted, and most of the characters are unlikable. I do have to give it credit for not being as racist or terrible as I had expected. Bonus points for the TigerDirect product placement. You probably already own this game as part of a THQ bundle pack. Otherwise, I wouldn't buy it.

reviewText:
OK while it lasted.  It took me five hours to complete the game and I tend to take my time.  Not that you really get a chance to do that in this game.  It is basically non-stop action while it lasts.  If you like that you will like the game.  The story and characters do not leave any impression.  Just there to move the action along.

Overall, I would say do not buy unless you get it for a couple bucks or in a bundle for cheap.  The game is short.  There is zero replay value.  It is on rails which is slightly noticable in say COD but very noticible in this title.  There are a bunch of irratating things I would blame on poor programming.  Such as getting entangled with your AI support, not moving because their is some object you can not see but is seemingly too high for you to walk over, AI enemies fire and explosions affecting  only you, etc.  At one point I was waiting for my AI team to open a door so we could move forward but we were stuck for some reason.  I spent a few minutes running around trying to see if there was something needed that I missed.  It turns out, the AI engineer guy was stuck on something outside and I had to walk into him a few times to free him and then he joined us at the door inside and we moved forward.

So, not the worst but no where near the best.

reviewText:
I purchased this game out of love for my country.
Seriously, if you are a very patriotic American, get this game.

For everyone else, here is my review.

Campaign: 6/10
Very good job not censoring out graphic bits, those bad bits really instilled in me a very good motivation to fight. However, the plot line suffered from a HORRIBLE lack of character development: at the very end I wasn't even shaken up at all (won't go in more depth for fear of spoiling). In addition, while half awake I beat the campaign in around 3.5 hours; anyone else would probably beat it in 2 hours.

Gameplay: 3/10
Basically Call of Duty, except you can't shoot through materials.

Multiplayer: 1/10
Dead, I found around 8 servers, all except one had 0 people.

The only reason I can recommend this game is the extreme patriotism and other emotions that this game can make one feel. This game goes 75% off relatively often, pick it up then.

reviewText: This is a difficult game to recommend, which is ultimately why I chose not to. Everything about this game had the makings to compete with the COD series, but it continually fell just short or was consistent throughout the game. A great example of that consistency is the story. When the story first starts and it hits the fan, the story is powerful and driving you on. You feel compelled to take back your country. That get's lost not even half-way through and then you are left doing the standard shoot-em-up gig which leaves a very hollow feeling after having seen what should have been.\n\nThe game really isn't bad, and is definitely worth a few bucks if on sale, but I cannot honestly recommend this game with so many other and better qualified games out there.
