reviewText:
tl;dr: A bunch of great ideas with poor execution: the game. This game isn't really worth the $20 asking price. Campaign is three hours long on a good day, and the mulitplayer is a bland, unpopulated experience. For the same price you can buy battlefield 3 or 4 on Origin, which outclass this game in just about every aspect. Don't waste your time here.

What it does right: I was hyped as hell when this first showed up, and the amount of advertisement and weird ♥♥♥♥ they did at E3 that year really made me want to buy it. The setting is a great idea. I wish more shooters would stray away from the modern military shooter that we're so used to by now and do things like this. However, when the reviews started coming out I'd figure I'd try it once it dropped in price... four years later.

The mechanics work, I guess. It's nothing special, other than maybe getting to use the Goliath to shoot rockets at enemies that are giving you a hard time. None of the guns feel bad to use, and they have a good amount of punch on enemies, but at the same time they do feel kinda flimsy. For a shooter that came out in 2011, it works. It's nothing special but it's not like the mechanics of the game are terrible.

A few of the set pieces were pretty cool, but those were a mix between laughable and alright. None of it felt particularly epic, but again, it served its purpose.

What it does wrong: Oh boy where to start. I guess we can start with the singleplayer. It's overly linear. I don't mean the good kind of linear like Metro 2033 or Killzone. I mean straight out of call of duty corridoor nose-leading. If you go in any direction other than which one the game wants you to go, you'll run face first into an invisible wall. It doesn't matter if you just passed through that open door ten seconds ago, you go one way and one way only. And you can tell the designating fighting zones from the talking corridors by the random stacks of chest-high cover littered around. It's painfully obvious that this game doesn't really want you to go out on your own or do anything other than move from cover to cover shooting bad guys. There is no variety to any of it.

The graphics also haven't aged well. I don't think they were even that great at the time. I think Half Life 2 looks better and it came out seven years before. The color scheme is bland and uninteresting, and you can't interact with anything other than picking up guns. Even your teammates have to open doors for you like this was a ps2 ww2 shooter.

The campaign is, in its entirety, maybe three hours long if you stop to look at the scenery once in a while. I beat it in two and a half. It isn't even a good three hours either. I was actually kinda thankful it wasn't longer, otherwise I might not have gotten through it. None of your npc companions are even remotely interesting and they don't bother to characterize any of them beyond very basic traits. You have no reason to be invested in any of it, as they just sling you into the action three minutes into it with barely any explanation. This doesn't change the further you get into it, either. Only after following these rebels for an hour and a half or so do they finally tell me in the form of an off-hand comment that they needed me to fly a helicopter for them. You think they would have taken the time to brief the pilot on that important detail, or at least asked if he could fly a helicopter and wasn't just a jet pilot or something.

The most motivation you get is the objective marker. No overall reason behind it, or important motive, just follow the arrow. Sure, I want to liberate the home of the free just as much as anyone, but blindly following the first couple of idiots that almost kill me in a car crash doesn't seem like it's the most solid of motivations.

And another thing, I'm getting really tired of silent protagonists. It worked in games like Dead Space because Isaac was completely alone, and didn't need to talk to anyone most of the time, but here? There are usually three other people that need to be interacted with in combat situations. Games like Far Cry 3 and Spec Ops: The Line have completely destroyed the notion that video game protagonists are better silent. I have no interest in Jacobs like I did Jason. Being invested in your character as a person goes a long way into being better invested in the game overall. This game did nothing towards this and ended up being bland and forgettable.

One last little rant before I get to the multiplayer: North Korea? Really? The only reason anyone ever gives them any respect is because they're allies with China. Never would a tiny, economically weak nation like North Korea ever be able to hold as much land as we are led to believe, or be able to invade and occupy the nation with the world's strongest military, even while under economic collapse.  The logistics of such things are simply impossible for North Korea, even if they did have the military size they say they do, which is most likely a lie. As much as I give battlefield 4's singleplayer ♥♥♥♥, it at least had a believable scenario. Plus North Korean soldiers using Colt, Bushmaster, and Kriss USA firearms (All American-based firearm companies if you didn't know)? Did they even bother to do any research into this matter?

Now for the Multiplayer: They tried to add some unique features like battlepoints to build up like killstreaks, using this money to spawn into vehicles and use special weapons. I like this better than cod's killstreak system, since it allows you to buy things even if you're not doing that well, but I still don't like it that much. First, just about every class gets a rocket launcher, and you can buy it after one kill. This is not good game design. Vehicles are pretty much useless beyond a quick kill or two if you find a group of enemies that knows what they're doing. Vehicles are pretty much instant kills on infantry too, so that's annoying, and you can't even use environmental ques to tell where they are like you might in battlefield, where you might hear it coming or see it firing on the minimap. I think it did show up on the minimap, but I never saw it before one killed me.

It's got the standard setup for multiplayer unlocking systems. Get kills and unlock guns. I didn't play enough to unlock anything, but I never felt like using anything other than the first class was really necessary. I didn't see much variety in the enemies either, but then again the killcam gives you absolutely no information other than where the person who killed you was at. Since just about every class gets a rocket launcher, and sniping is pretty pointless on smaller maps imo, there didn't seem to be much variety to be had. I played a few games and there wasn't much exciting going on. The maps are too big for there to be large chunks of action, and I doubt that's ever going to change with the player counts as they are. Other games do everything so much better.

Overall, this game is nothing but all of the stereotypical elements of first person shooters from 2011. It seems like a lazy attempt to pull away customers from cod's fanbase, and even then, it doesn't do anything better than call of duty, it just imitates it in a different setting. If this game had come out on the ps2 seven years before, then I think it might have been a lot better received. As it is now, that's kinda what it feels like: a generic ww2 shooter from the ps2 made for a later generation. There's nothing special about it other than its setting. The multiplayer is bland, the singleplayer is forgettable, and the entire thing is nothing but a cynical attempt at checkboxing fps elements to try to bring in the cod crowd.

If you read this far and are still thinking about buying the game, please don't. I can not in good conscience recommend this game to anyone when battlefield 4, an infinitely better experience, is the exact same price. Buy that game for a much better fps experience.

reviewText: This is a difficult game to recommend, which is ultimately why I chose not to. Everything about this game had the makings to compete with the COD series, but it continually fell just short or was consistent throughout the game. A great example of that consistency is the story. When the story first starts and it hits the fan, the story is powerful and driving you on. You feel compelled to take back your country. That get's lost not even half-way through and then you are left doing the standard shoot-em-up gig which leaves a very hollow feeling after having seen what should have been.\n\nThe game really isn't bad, and is definitely worth a few bucks if on sale, but I cannot honestly recommend this game with so many other and better qualified games out there.

reviewText:
-Guns have no kick whatsoever, enemies are bullet-sponges - gunplay in general feels weak.

-Story is linear, not in the least stimulating, and feels incredibly contrived.

-Graphics are passible but look aged - which given the age of the game isn't surprising. However, other games from the time have aged much better (Bad Company 2 for example, is a year older but looks much better IMO).

-However, on the positive side - the campaign is only 4 hours long and I paid $0.98 for this at Walmart.

If you can get it for less than $5 (I almost begrudged the $1.13 I paid for it, taxes in), you might find something to like here. Although the multiplayer is dead, if it's cheap enough, the campaign MIGHT be worth it to you. As PC Gamer's Andy Chalk so accurately put it - this is essentially the video game equivalent of Sharknado - if that's your thing, go ahead and take a look. Otherwise stay clear.

-on the plus side however, the sequel looks to be an entirely different genre of shooter. One that it looks like I could enjoy-

reviewText:
Single player campaign felt canned, but I enjoyed the multiplayer. I thought the campaign had a good story but was EXTREMELY linear. The developer could've done so much more with what the writers had done. Perhaps open world?

In particular, I enjoyed the point-based, multiplayer reward system that allowed players to purchase air strikes, drones, weapons, or vehicles.

I also enjoyed the map system that unlocked new parts of the map, depending on which team captured objectives.

Overall, it wasn't a great shooter, but it was good and offered a few different features than most other FPS.

reviewText:
not worth the hassle really. Ive tried playing this but it dosent run very well on my system for some reason. i easily have enough spec on my pc to play this game but no matter even if i put every detail down to low quality i still only max out at 30 fps. it runs no better on very low options than at high quality. Im getting killed far too many times because of the crazy lag trying to play it. its really frustrating in the middle of a chapter having to go back to the main menu several times trying options to get it to run smoother. ive tried replaying every chapter a few times but its running no better!
Its a shame because the actual game would not be that bad, not a classic but definitley would not be bad.  its a far fetched story but entertaining enough. As graphics go its quite very good in my opinion, very athmospheric at dusk running through abandoned destroyed american towns and seeing the snow capped rockies in the distant. Gun play would be ok too only im struggling because of the low fps going from 30 fps one minute to 10 fps the next.
Its also far too linear and sometimes your teammates get in your way and you cannot move leaving a north korean to pump you with bullets.
Good points.
Graphics
Entertaining enough story

Bad Points.
runs poorly on my system
Story far too short
too linear
Pure awkward to move sometimes, teammates getting in way, clumsy.

All in All i couldnt really recommend this game, because it just wont run for me. I have Battlefield 4, which is a game that demands far more on a system than homefront and it still runs better for me!

reviewText:
Soooo...Homefront, homefront. This is kinda an odd game to speak, I mean it's not a very good game but nor is it bad. Originally as many recall this game was developed by THQ before they went bankrupt, after which they sold the rights to the developers of Crysis and the game was back on steam (after the companus bankrupcy it was removed from steam for some odd reason)

So, Homefront takes place in the far future where the leader of North Korea is dead, his son took over and somehow managed to unify the North and South Korea (wishful thinking much?), then they somehow take over Japan and China. While this is going on the US is being kicked around like a Juarez ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, going bankrupt and losing it's major wars in the middle east (Oh hey, George Bushes worst dream came true, America no longer having a big ♥♥♥♥), being hit by a deadly bird flu an etc. All this leaves America crippled and North Korea rolls in an takes ground, an it's up to the glorious resistance to save America an all it's Apple pie/Burger king eating citizens from the evil Korean cooking.

Now, if you read trough this synopsis and haven't blown your brains out, then congrats you're the small part of us squishy humans that likes using their brain thingies.

Yes, this script reads like something a basement dwelling paranoid whackjob would write and then put on youtube, because it is. The script for this game was writen by John Millius, the same clown who wrote Red Dawn -frankly, you'd think after THAT stink burger someone would take away his writing pen-, and he pretty much brings the same jingoism here as he did in Red Dawn. To make it short, in Miliuse's eyes anyone who isn't American is apperantly a equivilent of a Nazi, because as in Red Dawn, the Koreans in this game do everything except twirlling moustache's or having swastikas. It's clear they are trying to make you hate these guys with every cheap way possible, which just comes off as juvenile and laughable (or maybe I really don't care 'cause I'm not American an the plot to this game is seven layer cakes of stupid)

Anyway, let's forget the stupid plot and speak about the gameplay itself. Aaaan...there isn't much to say really, the game is your standart Modern Military shooter, if you played enough CoD you pretty much got this in the bag. The game can be clocked out in four hours tops (if you don't die that often) and after that there's an abrupt end for the upcoming sequel (which I honestly wanna see, it kinda seems more promising than this game.) The weapons are standart, the characters are all bland as hell, you are silent and actually don't have the ability to open doors for some unknow reason.

Honestly, I'd say the real best part of this game is the multiplayer itself. It has 32 players limit, it def feels more like a Bad Company 2 or something Battlefield esque, rather than CoD arena/twitch reflexes shooting. There's some fun maps and mods, and it really feels like you're on a battle.

Now, can I recommend this game?  Well, I'd say you should only buy it on sales and just for the multiplayer itself, because the single player isn't really worth it.

reviewText:
Homefront is a bland game.

The campaign's theme is great and originally what made me interested in the game, but the gameplay consists mostly of running through corridors and following AI buddies onsiderably slower than you. And you know how in regular FPS's you start off with meager equipment and get more and stronger toys throughout the game? Homefront bizarrely does the reverse. It gradually strips away your best guns and gimmicks and mission by mission turns the game more from a semi-interesting FPS to a run-to-the-mill shootmans. Thankfully you won't have to suffer long because the campaign is super short. You can easily blitz through it in five or so hours on normal difficulty.

Multiplayer is dead to no-one's surprise.

Skip this game and look forward to Homefront 2: Revolution instead. Coming in 2016 from Dambuster Studios and Deep Silver (latter being the guys who bought the publishers of this first Homefront, THQ).

Get rescued from concentration camp by insurgent forces, got through hell to get away...have to wait for AI to open every single door, because they have the majic kick the door in ability.

Get stuck on wall, because I walked into it. Reload checkpoint...move forward.

Hail of gunfire yet I can here screaming child

Grenade magically appears next to me, die.

Lose ability to walk at normal pace so that I can hear about the insurgent camp. regain when devs are through boring me.

Bounce off open door, open staircase and several othe invisible objects until my team goes ahead of me through them. Devs must be implying that my character has a stong sense of the ...last out" mentality.

reviewText: This has to be one of the most racist, stupid, poorly written, macho plies of rubbish that has ever been made into a game.  It’s a low water mark for games and is just about everything wrong with FPS. This game feels like an ad for the tea party and NRA. Cliché and after cliché seem to make up this guns and glory rubbish.  Boring and an unimaginative in its ideas the game itself has so many flaws but worst of all it fails to do even the simplest thing a game can be, to be fun. You must stand and wait for the world’s most stereotypical resistance fighter (ripped out of some 80’s action B movie) brown leather jacket man. This man walks everywhere , not once does he run! In the middle of a fire fight he walks. Out number and out gunned, he walks.  I seem to have spent more time waiting for this character whose name I can’t even recall then shooting at anyone. To add insult to injury if you shoot him you don’t get get the satisfaction of taking him out of the game. Bullets have no effect on this leather jacket wearing fool.  There is nothing new in this game and what is in it has been done better. The story is wake, the gameplay is dull and it is just a waste of money and time .

reviewText:
not worth the hassle really. Ive tried playing this but it dosent run very well on my system for some reason. i easily have enough spec on my pc to play this game but no matter even if i put every detail down to low quality i still only max out at 30 fps. it runs no better on very low options than at high quality. Im getting killed far too many times because of the crazy lag trying to play it. its really frustrating in the middle of a chapter having to go back to the main menu several times trying options to get it to run smoother. ive tried replaying every chapter a few times but its running no better!
Its a shame because the actual game would not be that bad, not a classic but definitley would not be bad.  its a far fetched story but entertaining enough. As graphics go its quite very good in my opinion, very athmospheric at dusk running through abandoned destroyed american towns and seeing the snow capped rockies in the distant. Gun play would be ok too only im struggling because of the low fps going from 30 fps one minute to 10 fps the next.
Its also far too linear and sometimes your teammates get in your way and you cannot move leaving a north korean to pump you with bullets.
Good points.
Graphics
Entertaining enough story

Bad Points.
runs poorly on my system
Story far too short
too linear
Pure awkward to move sometimes, teammates getting in way, clumsy.

All in All i couldnt really recommend this game, because it just wont run for me. I have Battlefield 4, which is a game that demands far more on a system than homefront and it still runs better for me!

reviewText:
Homefront is a really good game, but it is very ragged. On first look it is just another FPS, but in every game we fight against Russia or recently China. This game has another enemy which is Korea, who jumped on America. We must fight as one of homefront soliders against the aggressor.
Missions are mixed, one time we just shooting, and the other time we have to remotly control some vehicle which helps us to defeat our enemies. For special mention deserves the last mission, which is full of action, and gives us great ending of story.

Ups:
- Story
- New look on War
- ruthless aggressor
- sneaking missions
- AI

Downs:
- Bugs
- invisible walls
- a little clunky gameplay

Neutral:
- Graphic - it isn't great, but it isn't bad.

reviewText:
Easily one of the worst games I have ever played.

In the singleplayer campaign there is an incredibly cheap blatant attempt to give some sort of meaning, pull at emotion or whatever it was they intended by having dozens of civilians executed and mowed down by gunfire and wanton violence more vicious than Hitler's SS would dream, and not all too longer after those instances you're introduced to a mass grave.

Where in Mass Effect 3 they managed to summarize the global genocide of humanity on Earth by focusing on the death of a single kid being killed in a shuttle shot down as Shepard leaves, this game utterly failed after tossing hundreds of dead civilians at your face. It is a ♥♥♥♥ing disgrace.

When it comes to multiplayer, I have no idea. After joining a server I spawned and proceeded to get sniped within a few seconds several times until I just quit the game and uninstalled. I never saw a single person and never will unless someone pays me to play that ♥♥♥♥♥.

I rather have spent the $5 put towards this game on a big bag of Skittles.

reviewText: A bit dull and generic, the movement and gunplay seems to be intentionally almost identical to recent Call Of Duty games. Completely forgettable storyline. No unique or interesting features. Bought it when it was on sale, but still regret it. Found occasional bugs, nothing game-breaking, mostly weird texture issues, or parts where I'd have to restart a checkpoint for something not my fault.\n\nEdit: Why has this got downvoted a ton, the reference to Call Of Duty? reviewText: A first-person shooter by every definition of the term, but not a particularly interesting one. The plot is at least an interesting take on the same old America-vs.-commies plot we've all grown used to and the voice acting is actually quite good, but the gameplay doesn't really do enough to supplement it. Your character feels like he moves too slow, the enemies are far too numerous, the levels aren't very variable and even the guns feel weirdly... soggy. They don't have the oomph" that the weapons of games like Call of Duty do. It reallyt is a shame

reviewText:
Oh
My
God.

This is possibly the worst generic first person shooter there is, you thought that all the CODs are bad? You've seen nothing yet,  this is...linear corridor heavily scripted fest...which lasts 5 hours! I hated every minute I spended in this game. And it was just 5 hours, jesus, jesusity christ.


You would except big polish from games like this, say what you want about CODs, yes they kind of suck,but when it comes to polish and detail they tend to be rather good. This game..you can't even see the hands of the main hero when he's clmbing. The only good thing that came out of this game was the soundtrack, which is really good and I remember it to this day...multiplayer was decent, nobody plays it anymore of course, so there's no point mentioning it, as you are not going to be playing it.

The story....eeeuuugh Korea (lol) takes over the entire world (lolololol) and some other crap I don't care about, all characters are generic, you've got your gurl soldier, your ♥♥♥♥♥♥ soldier and your silent Gordon Freeman protagonist. Oh, and there is some guy who dies, he is charming. The game really wants to shock you, first thing you see is soldiers killing son's parents in front of his eyes. It gets old.

I also remember this game having some poor optimization with mediocre graphics to go along with it. The game had super big hype, and it didn't deliver on it. At all.

Gameplay...Call of Duty...regenerating health...two weapons limit....gunplay's the same...what more can I possibly say?

And there is boss at the end! QTE boss! Have fun!

There is apparently next game in the works by Crytek. So I guess next Homefront is going to be graphics ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game with the same gameplay of this game? I'll pass.



Sooo...in the end..any pluses? Well...the game's super short...and the soundtrack, I really like the soundtrack.

3/10

reviewText:
You know how you remember certain moments in a game, when you got all excited you did this and that happened, well none spring to mind with homefront.

A brief and dull affair badly trumped in my opinion by bulletstorm.

If being comparative is left to one side we have an FPS playing out a rather generic possible reality where natural resources are so scarce that its every man for himself. Usher in the words resistence and government and you have the well done dish of the day that is one world governance as country after country slaves for out right dominance, sadly with you not invited. Your tubed from one section to the next with little concern for connecting or indentifying with friendly AI others. The weapons are bland and more a rat, at, tat than a thud, thud of bullets ripping there way through the enemy AI's torso. Graphics and sound are unrevolutionary and single play very very short.

You see no matter how you slice it and dice it, this game comes up familiar and wanting so unless its cheaper than the asking price when your making a decision, there are others better suited to waste time on.

reviewText:
I'm ready for the hot sequel

Francefront.

Combat heavily armed insurgents, I mean democratic freedom fighters, from the religion of peace. How will you survive being shamed by your own native citizens for wanting to maintain an ethnic heritage? How dare you want to close the mighty gates of immigration! You personally owe your success to everyone else in the world! You didn't build that! Open the gates or you are a racist!

Hard mode takes place in Sweden.




Anyway Homefront is a pretty badass Korean BBQ simulator.

Disregard how Korea's military budget of 7 trillion trumped the 577 trillion the US uses for defense, plus the 2nd Amendment.

Be absolutely sure to buy this game when it goes on sale. It was never worth the initial asking price of 50 bucks due to its brevity, but the campaign is a unique twist on the cowadooty forumla.

reviewText: The campaign was over before it really started. It was only a few hours long and it felt like the beginning of a much longer game that might have had potential. As it is, it's a  very short standard linear modern shooter. It got frustrating having to wait for an NPC to open a door or remove an obstacle so the story can progress. The graphics looked nice at times and also some of the weapons were a lot of fun to shoot. There's a helicopter part thrown in that was entertaining. I played one game of multiplayer on the only server (it was laggy) that's still up. I'd say give Homefront a try if you're bored and the game is on sale for cheap.

reviewText:
My rating: 3.5 / 10

The majority of the entertainment that can be derived from Homefront is mostly just from how remarkably terrible it is, as it achieves nothing more than being an underwhelming and bug ridden CoD clone.

Pros:
- A number of creative scenarios for the player that adds some variety to the gameplay.
- Soundtrack isn't too bad.
- Representation of an Asian American video game character.

Cons:
- Very glitchy, from overall player control, to physics errors, to scripted events failing to play out correctly.
- Enemy AI is very rough around the edges. Sometimes being completely dumb, and other times having the precision of a super computer.
- Bland story, with a rather anti-climactic ending.
- Dialogue hardly makes sense in some cases, making the characters appear incredibly unintelligent.
- Very short singleplayer campaign, though in the case of this game, it's probably a plus.

Homefront probably could have been a decent game, had it been given the proper attention and resources during development, as there were some points that showed a bit of potential. However, unfortunately this was nowhere near enough to redeem how glitchy and poorly put together the final product ended up being.

reviewText:
Sweet merciful CRAP was that a short game or what? Steam says that I played 3 hours of it, and that's not even an I-beat-it-quicker-than-you brag; I was trying to explore.

Anyway, I thought it was awesome. The campaign is insanely epic, even if there are some annoying parts, and the shooting mechanics are absolutely top-notch. The guns react amazingly, and if you have a decent sound system, you can really feel each shot.

The graphics aren't the greatest if you get right up close, but for the most part they're pretty good. Character models and animations are very well done, so that's at least something.

If I'd paid $60 for it, I would be livid, but as I paid more like $7 for it, I think it was worth it. Check it out if you like shooters, and can find it on sale.

I have no comment on multiplayer, as I don't care for competitive shooters in the slightest.

reviewText:
Homefront 5/10

It's okay. Multiplayer is dead, so don't even bother. Obviously that's what this game was meant for, but the community just hasn't held up on this.

The campaign is decent, but really short. The story behind it is good and the intro level is very emotional and shocking. However it loses that feeling and becomes a pretty cliche military shooter with alot of over the top cinematics, lots of bullet sponging, and some frustrating deaths. It's enjoyable, but nothing exceptional.

reviewText: Buy something else. Play CoD, or BC:2. The Singleplayer is kind of hollow, even if it has some interesting visuals, gameplay isn't really there. Multiplayer feels like a mix of the afformentioned two games, but the guns feel like toys, and you die without warning almost every time you spawn. Sniped from across the map or shot in two seconds, when under fire, you just die. There's no time to react. I'm not much for spawn kill die spawn kill die. There's no tactics, and everyone on the teams seem confused about what they're supposed to be doing. Only plus is the interesting perk system, in which you have points to spend on abilities that have different costs. This makes for a few effective mixes, but with the rest of the multiplayer being so disappointing, I have to rate it 2/5.\nOtherwise, I'm looking at Brink and Battlefield 3 for better multi, and even if Crysis 2 bombs for multi, the singleplayer in the first game was better than anything in Homefront.

reviewText:
Terrible, Terrible, Terrible.

The trailer was the best part of the game.  I had such high hopes for the storyline and that it was written by the Red Dawn author.

Things that sucked in my opinion:

*No HP/HUD - Regenerative Health
*Endlessly respawning North Koreans
*AI was terrible - could hit a guy and not take him out, but then he would lose interest in me if I ducked around a corner
*Hit boxes - I could shoot a guy in the shoulder and be given a head shot - hurray for sniping with a shot gun
*Rockets that can hit me from around the corner - how did the enemy know where I was to curve his rocket around?
*Being yelled at by my allies where to go and whom to shoot - Constantly

The gameplay was tedious. I didn't even bother finishing the game. My one regret was spending money and time purchasing and playing this game.  I would rather have punched myself in the nuts for 3 hours while being yelled at in Korean than play this game.

Do-not-purchase-this-game!  If you gift this game to someone, you deserve all the bad that can possibly befall you.

reviewText: Come on, what is this ? People who thought the latest Call Of Duties were short, prepare for a new contender. That's right, even with a small pause inbetween, I finished it in 4 hours. It's ridiculous for a full priced game. For the first time I really feel like I've wasted my money. Now, don't get me wrong; it's a good game, but you jump from one scenario to another one way too soon. There should've been more (or longer anyway) missions. And I don't think the multiplayer added something new to the genre. It's dull and from the start there were too many campers sitting around. Say what you want, but Call Of Duty is still king of (over the top) FPS storytelling and, in my opinion, the multiplayer experience just can't be beat. Get this game when it's $10-15.\n\n[Rating: 77/100]

reviewText:
Don't bother. The game looks bad, it plays bad, and it's not even a great port. It looks like Blops 1 graphics, the guns all feel the same and pretty much ARE the same. The story is pretty terrible and cliche, North Korea taking over America + the rest of the world? Really? They could have chosen practically any other nation and it would have been more likely. The enemies have awful AI and the game plays with a mixture of the worst of Battlefield and CoD. It has wave after wave of idiot enemies like CoD, and it has the open maps of Battlefield which would be fine if not for the clown cars of koreans that arrive.

Go buy CoD, the story is generally the same junk, but at least most of the guns feel different from eachother and the AI isn't nearly as dumb.

Multiplayer is pretty much dead and suffers from the gunplay issue. Unless you have a fascination with Korea or are incredibly desperate for a FPS then pass this.

reviewText:
Korea took over the whole of USA, you are in the resistance fighting for freedom. But straight to the point
What is so good about this game?
This game will make your chills run through your body, nearly everytime, with the great voice acting and really violent scenes, you can feel the real pain of some of the victims of the war. This game will change the way you think about wars. It is completely different than any other shooter. With a great shooting engine, it is a joy to shoot. It might be short, which some people would think its good because it is not repetetive at all, every mission is different and it has different objectives, you will not get bored of this game.

Trust me, this is not just a game. Some gamers will wipe their tears off while playing this game. In my oppinion, worth every single dollar.

Multiplayer, you ask?
It is still running, there is just one server full everyday(not in night) and the best way to describe it, it is like COD but with big maps like Battlefield and added some great tech features which you can use, remote control helis with rockets, rc cars with machine gun on it, and many other.

reviewText:
Homefront, made by THQ, is a first-person-shooter where you are a resistance fighter in a near-future America, where the North Korean military have occupied your country, and you and the resistance fight for survival.

The Good:
- Atmosphere: The sense of loss and human suffering is really emphasized, children watching their parents being shot, mass graves, attrocities, done well.
- Graphics: while not the most detailed, they are rich and dynamic.

The Bad:
- Cover: Bullets can not even penertrate a cardboard box, enemies are often only killed when they deliberately show themselves. Not very tactical.
- Linear story: Singleplayer is the same, no exploration, and suffers from the you do as you're told" syndrome
date: much in the same was as Call of Duty.\n- Overscripted A.I: Trying to go through a door or down a ladder to early and the game will block you
recommended: forcing your teammates to go first. Very annoying and common.\n- Control: 90% of the time you are being told what to do / following someone\n- Random deaths: You may kill over 100 enemies in a battle
hoursPlayed: and then die from instantly from something???\n- Enemies: 90% cannon fodder infantry
voteText: the occasional tank / heli that is killed by an auto targeting ally.\n- Audio: Weapons sound fake
helpfulPercent: battle music is bland
votesHelpful: this is not the game's strong point.\n- Sprinting: My grandmother could run faster\n- Ammo: Hardly any can be carried
votesTotal: ammo is not shared between similar weapons.\n\nThis title was a dissapointment. THQ suffered from the poor sales and performance of this game. The singleplayer is linear
votesFunny: boring
commentsCount: predictable and frustraiting.\nAfter only 2 hours
column16: I had enough. This game played so badly
column17: with repeating objectives
column19: I uninstalled the game.\nI did not play the multiplayer
column20: but it looks like a bland mix of CoD and Frontlines. Hopefully crytek does a better job with the upcoming Homefront 2.\n\nScore: 3/10 (Bad)"

reviewText:
I've had this game for some time now and on my first play-through I couldn't understand what the developers were thinking. However, after letting the game sit for a while and going back to play it once more I have decided that this game is an underappreciated, if somewhat rough gem.

There are many aspects of the game that I simply adore, the attention to the detail in the collectable news reports is one of them; the absolute immersion into the politics of the time is simply brilliant, not to mention accurate. Along with this, I think that the story, which is the background story of the US being occupied, is fascinating. Usually in games the US is at the zenith of power and you have to save it from complete disaster, however here, in Homefront, the US has indeed fallen and it is the role of the resistance to attempt to rebuild. The preface for this game is wonderful and I simply love it, however there are many problems with the game mechanics, graphics and AI which let the game down. Unfortunately no matter how good the story is, playability is just as important.

One of the biggest issues with the game is the AI's seemingly scripted movements, lack of intelligence and spawning locations, making a few play-throughs rather predictable. It is a real pain to re-start at a check point, kill the very same enemies in the very same way, get killed, then do it all over again a few more times. The AI, for a realistic and enjoyable shooter needs to be a little unpredictable.
Continuing on from this theme of realism within the game brings me to another issue, the ballistics. I found a few times that I was being pinned down by an enemy but when returning fire it appears that I am out of range, which is strange because the longest distance you fire in the game is no more than 200 meters. For a good shooter the ballistics must be accurate; both the trajectory of the bullets and recoil need to be taken into account. The lack of recoil was not only unrealistic but frustrating
Another, and in a way a very disappointing problem is that I didn’t feel as though I was part of the resistance. The story, the concept and all the potential for a game to truly give you a resistance, grungy, underworld experience felt very much like every other shooter there is. As I said prior, I love the concept and the preface to the game, I think it is fantastic. The execution however was somewhat poorly done. You are dropped in the middle of the action without enough time to become attached to the correctors or the community. In a resistance situation, every single loss would be heartbreaking; I didn’t find that to be the case at all.
There are other issues along the same lines, such as a lack of interaction with the Oasis community; it would have been great if you spent some time gathering for supplies, cutting your teeth on a few raids and what not before embarking on the main story. The game was also far too short; I think that there could have been a few more missions that would have made the game more enjoyable.

I’ve probably given more criticism than praise, but that is because I wanted so desperately for this game to be good, but what stands out are the failings. This game has the potential to be great. After the release of the sequel I recommend the developers go back and re-do the original, fix it up and re-release it. I really do recommend the game if you’re able to look past the flaws, the concept is great and you’ll see just how good this game could have been.

All in all, 5.5/10

reviewText:
북한이 대조선련방으로 급성장하여, 붕괴된 미국을 공격하여
미국을 점렴한 상황...
그런 상황에서 전직 파일럿이였던 제이콥은
북한군에 잡혀 끌려가는 도중, 레지스탕스에게 도움을 받고
그도 레지스탕스와 함께 활동하여, 북한군들을 몰아내기 위해
여러 작전을 함께하게 되는데...

게임 자체의 스토리는 굉장히 자극적이며 잔혹하고 충격적인 게임내의
표현은 그나마 볼만했으나...

콜옵 마냥 일직선형적인 게임 구성이나 답답한 AI, 그리고 영 밋밋한 타격감,
일부 스토리에 쓰인 무인 전차를 제외하고 딱히 특징없는 게임 시스템.
나름 세계관을 잘 표현해낸것 같지만, 엉성한 후반부 스토리...

많은 아쉬움이 있던 FPS 게임이다. (멀티는 해보지 않았으므로 제외)
하지만 미국이 밀리며, 한편으론 억압받고, 한편으론 미쳐가는 사회를 잘 표현해 냈고
나름 박진감있게 표현하려고 했던 게임씬들 또한 그리 나쁘진 않았다.

끝을 조금 명확하게 표현하지 않고 끝냈기에
발전된 후속작을 기대해본다.

reviewText: While I enjoyed the style of this FPS set in a compelling near-future vision of the US, I found it to be seriously lacking in substance. I was also annoyed by the fact that it doesnt display the correct buttons to push for an x box controller, so I spent a lot of time mashing keys trying to work out what was button 8 to drop my flares or whatever.\n\nIt's not a terrible game and I really liked the back story, but I really can't recommend it as there just isn't enough meat on the bone.

reviewText:
Homefront has really nice graphics, and an entertaining storyline, following the tradition of the Red Dawn movies, and, I'm assuming, based on the Homefront movie. When reading about the game I thought this story line should have a lot of possibilites for great FPS action.

This game frequently uses the can't-retreat-tons-of-enemies scenario.  This forces a panicked death-match type of play at some point in most of the levels.  Additionally the game forces even more death-match style of kamakaze engagement by sometimes having a timed element.

For example, at one point you are trapped in a fairly small area with limited cover and have to protect a wheeled-drone type of tank from RPGs, while being shot at by the entire Korean army.  Unless you kill enough of  the RPG-shooters the tank is destroyed, forcing a restart of the level.  There is no option but to run-and-gun, suffering a lot of damage from  the Korean army, while trying to get enough of the RPGs to pass the level.

If you like the deathmatch style of playing against tons of bots, then you may like Homefront.  For me, frequently being forced into this style of play is one of the elements that end up being frustrating, rather than fun.  To make it worse, during these frantic engagements, one of your team-mates continues to repeat some instruction, maybe as a hint"?  For example in the RPG scenario
hoursPlayed: "get the RPG in the third floor window"
voteText: or "...on the rooftop".  This extremely loud repetition becomes so irritating
helpfulPercent:
that I played the last couple of tries with the sound muted.

Following are some other game-play related issues:

The character control seems very sluggish
votesHelpful: compared to other shooters-- almost like playing in slightly slow motion
votesTotal: while the rest of the game is normal speed.\n\nJumping up from a crouch is about half the speed of the enemies who jump from  behind cover to shoot.  This is especially frustrating
votesFunny: as there is no leaning implemented in the game.  So you have to jump up from behind cover in slow motion
commentsCount:
getting shot a couple of times before you are even up.

You can only jump the equivalent of about a foot off the ground. Even low obstacles force going around.

Sprinting is a lot slower than the AI team-mates-- they always pull ahead
column16: even though you are supposed to follow them.\n\nThis character motion problem is a little subtle
column17: but very noticible after just playing other shooters with much better character control.  At first I thought maybe something was wrong on my machine
column18: until I watched a playthrough of a level I just completed on YouTube.  Same thing-- slightly slow-motion
column19: compared with the rest of the game
column23: forcing switching guns frequentore ly with fallen enemies.  This is also very "death-match'ish" and lessens the realism
column24: as the last thing a real soldier wants on the battlefield is to pick up and use an unfamiliar weapon.  To make it worse
column25: the guns of fallen enemies dissappear pretty quickly.\n\nI finally gave up on the game during a follow-me type of sequence.  You are supposed to "sneak" through this survivalist camp in broad daylight while "insane survivalists" are walking all around.  The game hint says to follow this team-mate and stay low.  After about four times of literally following so close we were touching
column26: I gave up.\n\nThe scenario is so-- well
column27: dumb.  Broad daylight? no cover? enemies all around? Even touching the "leader" still resulted in being seen in a couple of minutes.  This was just too arbitrary
column28: and anti-immersive. It pulled me right out of the game.\n\nOver all the experience for me was more frustration than fun.  With so many other games to try
column29:
I'm done with this one for now .

I'm just really glad I got Homefront on a weekend sale.
"

reviewText: For a shooter that has mainly been ignored in the FPD community, I'm surprized on how good it was. The campain was ok, but could be better. I did not like that they pretty much threw you in the world with no backstory on your character or what was going on. Also, the campain itself was short as hell (only 4 hours on normal difficuly, and that includes dying a bunch of times). That being said, the best part about the game in my opinion is the multiplayer which is a mix of both call of duty and battlefield. Its like call of duty in the way that you can go duck around shooting and killing and its very faced paced, and it is like battlefield in the sense that there are multiple game modes, vehicules, big map sizes, and tactic opportunities. I paid 4,99$ for the game, and at that price, it is a MUST buy for shooter fans or casual gamers. Even tough the game is from 2011, it looks beutifull on Ultra settings even with today's standarts. I'd rate it a 9 out of 10. It would have been a 10 if the campain was a little bit better. So what are you waiting for? Get this game now.

reviewText:
Really doesn't deserve, in my opinion, a lot of the negative critism it got. It isn't a great game by any stretch, though for a straight up shooter it does its job well. Its entertaining if all you want to do is gun down a lot of North Koreans and LOL at the cringeworthy patriotic nonsense it has going on. Put it this way, it sets out what it aimed to do a lot beter than any of the recent Call of Duty titles, though it does lack the polish of those titles. The story is typical pro-'murica patriotic garbage, but is written by the same guy that wrote Red Dawn so that much is to be expected.

The multiplayer is very entertaining also. Though I've only played this portion on he Xbox, I have no idea how it is on PC as of yet.

For £4, you can't go wrong. I wouldn't recommend buying this at £15 though.

reviewText:
북한이 대조선련방으로 급성장하여, 붕괴된 미국을 공격하여
미국을 점렴한 상황...
그런 상황에서 전직 파일럿이였던 제이콥은
북한군에 잡혀 끌려가는 도중, 레지스탕스에게 도움을 받고
그도 레지스탕스와 함께 활동하여, 북한군들을 몰아내기 위해
여러 작전을 함께하게 되는데...

게임 자체의 스토리는 굉장히 자극적이며 잔혹하고 충격적인 게임내의
표현은 그나마 볼만했으나...

콜옵 마냥 일직선형적인 게임 구성이나 답답한 AI, 그리고 영 밋밋한 타격감,
일부 스토리에 쓰인 무인 전차를 제외하고 딱히 특징없는 게임 시스템.
나름 세계관을 잘 표현해낸것 같지만, 엉성한 후반부 스토리...

많은 아쉬움이 있던 FPS 게임이다. (멀티는 해보지 않았으므로 제외)
하지만 미국이 밀리며, 한편으론 억압받고, 한편으론 미쳐가는 사회를 잘 표현해 냈고
나름 박진감있게 표현하려고 했던 게임씬들 또한 그리 나쁘진 않았다.

끝을 조금 명확하게 표현하지 않고 끝냈기에
발전된 후속작을 기대해본다.

reviewText:
8/10

Single Player: Pretty good campaign, it is fun, brutal and enjoyable. The only complaint i have with it is that it is short, it is only 6 hours give or take if you just sit down and play through it all the way as well as having a very abrupt ending that felt more like a cliff hanger than it did a conclusion.

Multiplayer: I'm enjoying the ♥♥♥♥ out of the multiplayer. I'm a person who enjoys battlefield games (as opposed to Call of duty, which i dont care for to much) and homefront, atleast to me, feels like how Call of Duty SHOULD have been made.  Fun vehicles that take no time what so ever to learn how to use (literally) mixed with non stop fluent combat with elements such as Drone combat (remote control drones with guns on them) and Air strikes as well as the Battle Point system.

Why do i give it an 8/10?

Single player to short

Multiplayer has some issues such as:
Sniper rifles being way to OP (nerf coming in next patch)
Hackers (VAC currently not working)

reviewText: The reason the games story is so familiar and luring is that the game idea was written by the same guy that directed and wrote Red Dawn, Mr. John Milius. The graphics and sound in the game are very good but the game has a few bad traits that tarnished the single player experience for me. The controls are the typical FPS controls but the movement feels sluggish combined with a kind of snagged or hooked on door frames or stairs when trying to move around.  One of the most annying points of the game is the AI that you are supposed to follow, will sometimes sit there forever because the games dialogue trigger didnt register so you have back pedal 10 yards and rejoin the dude. There were some parts of the game that were straight up unbelievable due to the explosions and devestation yet you somehow survive. The game is fun and sad as player is forced to witness what war in the US would be like. I liked it and give it a  7/10.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
First the bad news:  The saving grace of this game, the multiplayer, has been shut down by Crytek after they purchased the rights from the failed THQ.  It really was a lot of fun when I played it, and I'm sad to see it go.  I really can't recommend the game on the singleplayer alone.

The PC version is done right, with more options than I've ever seen in a game before, including options for toggle controls and every graphics option you could ever want.  It's really too bad that all the effort that was put into doing this right is wasted on the now-crippled game.

The single player is short and full of lazy invisible wall level design, but the gameplay is solid.  The story is fairly interesting but nothing special.  It's better made than CoD, but that's not saying much.  In it's current state with no multiplayer, I wouldn't bother.

reviewText: Homefront is a FPS game, the graphics resembles Black Ops and Half Life 2 quite a bit, but it's not the graphics that makes this game amazing. It's the story. Starting by the intro-cinematic, the story comes to life, and is actually a VERY real bet on what COULD happen in the near future, so real in fact, that it scared me a bit. The amazing story in mind, and some solid gameplay - even though not very new in any way, it works nicely - the game is sadly very short, a dedicated player can finish it in about 4 hours, which seems to be the standard for FPS games these days. There is a Multi-Player part, but I'll leave that to you to explore for yourself :)
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I bought this game 90% for the SP... keep that in mind.

I have enjoyed the SP so far, about 85% done. The game runs great, but there are some times that the FPS drops to 25ish, but this is only for around one second or less. The game looks great in SP and the atmosphere is great. The sound is crazy. The weapons sound great, but the voices can be really quite then crazily loud for a little bit. Also, the voice overs can often be out of sync with the facial animations.

As for the MP, it is kind of BFBC2 scale, CoD gun handling, and Counter Strike/Crysis Wars currency system. BFBC2 is IMO much better, but there is some fun to be had in Homefront's MP. I have only spent 30-45 minutes in the MP so far and it seems I'll only continue it past the 5 hour mark when I'm with friends.

If the game were $60, I would say pass. If you are on the fence, wait till it is $40ish. If you are fairly interested, get it and lets pwn some noobs online.

4/5

reviewText:
There are issues with the single player storyline although it is fun. Your teammates can keep you alive, but they also make your job harder, especially Connor.  If you could kill him this game would be way shorter and way easier.

Spoiler:
In the bell-tower with all the enemies below and your teammates come back right below you and Connor decides to barrel across the way and then they tell you to come out as enemeies autospawn. Why? Why not just wait for you at the truck and let you get in and then drive to the next assignment? The makers wanted you to wade through autospawn attackers?  The level was too easy or too short otherwise? I don't know.

Second Spoiler:
In the helicopter, you are supposed to destroy tankers.  They are invincible so you have to hijack them instead. Your team gets in tankers and suddenly you are responsible to keep them safe.  They were just invincible 10 seconds before for crying out loud! Call me a whiner, but hopefully the game designers put themselves in the game as enemies so I could shoot them for it.

Teammates seem to exist mostly to keep you alive and annoy you at the same time. They offer endless distractions with their cries for help. Did I mention they are invincible? Yes, the unkillable annoyances, sort of like coworkers and siblings.

Why would I recommend the game?  Multiplayer.  Singleplayer is fun, but has annoyances.

reviewText:
When I bought this game I was expecting a fun and enjoyable Red Dawn style FPS game. While the graphics are superb and the storyline seems fantastic it is very easy to tell that it is a console to PC port.

The controls are horribly stiff, adjusting the sensitivities are almost a must and it is still impossible to get the kind of precision one would get when playing Counter-Strike or other PC-based FPS games. Vehicle combat is far worse with the controls going sluggish because of the way the sensitivities are built into the game.

For its story I would recommend the game alone. For gameplay I wouldn't have bought it if the Demo had reflected the poor and sluggish controls.

reviewText:
The year is 2027. The world as we know it is unraveling after fifteen years of economic meltdown and widespread global conflict over dwindling natural resources.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-6m93qF048k
A once proud America has fallen, her infrastructure shattered and military in disarray. Crippled by a devastating EMP strike, the USA is powerless to resist the ever expanding occupation of a savage, nuclear armed Greater Korean Republic.

Abandoned by her former allies, the United States is a bleak landscape of walled towns and abandoned suburbs. This is a police state where high school stadiums have become detention centers, and shopping malls shelter armored attack vehicles. A once-free people are now prisoners… or collaborators… or revolutionaries.

Join the Resistance, stand united and fight for freedom against an overwhelming military force in Homefront’s gripping single player campaign penned by John Milius (Apocalypse Now, Red Dawn). Stand alongside a cast of memorable characters as an emotional plot unfolds in this terrifyingly plausible near-future world.

Experience visceral, cinematic first-person shooter action as you fight your way across Occupied USA using guerrilla tactics, and commandeer military vehicles and advanced drone technology to defeat the enemy.

reviewText: This is another one of the quasi-realistic, near-future first person shooters.  What sets this apart from the Calls of Duty is it's visceral depiction of a failed America and the possible future that could conceivably come to pass.  The mechanics are solid and the graphics are nice -the story is decent but seems to stop abruptly.  An aspect in which this game shines is the sound of the guns.  Each report is a heavy, metallic blow that makes you feel like you may actually be listening to a battle rather than hail on a tin roof.  There are some scenes in the story that were so intensly that it made my blood boil and my stomach wrench -I have never felt so much anger at an artificial enemy as I did for these North Koreans -kudos Kaos Studios.  The battlepoints system for the multiplayer is a fun addition to the genre.  This game should not be overlooked: I recommend it.

reviewText:
Homefront is a straight-forward and very enjoyable FPS, based on the premise of Far Eastern forces attacking and invading the USA. There are some very good set pieces in the game, a large array of weapons to pickup and utilise (only two of which can be carried at anyone time) and laid heavily with some great, convincing voice acting.

Although still some distance behind Half-Life 2, Homefront did occasionally dip into that 'righteous campaign' feel that HL2 managed so well. You did get the feeling of David & Goliath - being hopelessly outnumbered, but fighting on for a true cause, regardless.

The game itself is only short - it took me a mere 4hrs to complete the SP campaign and I hardly raced through it. But its a clever, rewarding and worthy game of attention.

A solid 8.5/10

reviewText:
In a singleplayer game, Homefront is a typical FPS game. The gameplay is buggy, the story is okay, nothing new here.

On the other hand, multiplayer is pretty fun, with 32 players slots per game, large maps and open space, gain BP by killing and supporting, and then spend it for cool gadgets and vehicles. Still, it has one biggest issue, the few players issue. Most servers are empty.

Here's my recommendation. If you really want to play Homefront, try Homefont on the console (which has more playes) or wait for Homefront 2 instead (and wish it has more players), but if you want a good team based multiplayer FPS with weapon customization and lots of players on PC, try Call of Duty or Battlefield instead,

reviewText:
tl;dr - An amazing story that suffered from a critically short campaign and a crappy tacked-on multiplayer. Worth it for $20.

Homefront has an amazingly rich backstory and a wonderful premise based on speculation of current world events.  I was incredibly excited to get this game immediately when it came out and dove straight into the campaign.  The story was good, if a bit linear.  There wasn't a lot of room for exploration and invention, though the non-interactive elements of the environment looked fantastic.  I let myself get drawn into the the story and setting.

I noticed a few critical flaws.  First, the controls were not always intuitive.  When new weapons or situations arose later in the game, there was little to no explanation on how to take advantage of this.  (I had to go into the keybinds to figure out how to pilot the helicopter, for example.)  Some weapons were very under-utilized, appearing useful once or twice but otherwise pointless.

The end of the campaign was amazing from a story perspective -- and then simply ended.  That was it.  That's the game, thanks for playing.  I had five hours of gameplay and I'd completed the campaign.  It felt like a solid 'Act One' that had absolutely nothing else to it.

That's not entirely true ... there was a multiplayer component that was bland and wholly uninteresting, feeling like something they slopped into the game to claim 'Hey, we have multiplayer!' that flopped horribly.

At its current price of $20 I would say this is an entertaining single-player game you can enjoy for five or six hours.  Don't bother with the multiplayer aspect and try not to lose your mind over the sometimes awkward controls.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
N.B. Comments below are based on the single-player campaign.

It's short, ranging over 7 missions (it took me 5 1/2 hours), but at least these are action-packed and keep you 'entertained'. The missions offer a diversity of challenges, from sneak& sniper to vehicle missions. The weapons are standard fare, nothing out of the ordinary, but they work well with plenty of choice for everyone. Interesting is the Goliath automated vehicle.

The setting is interesting, the story is Ok, the characters are ... shallow and contradict themselves often - which ruins the setting and the story quite a bit.

Now to the biggest problem with the game: It is self-righteous, hypocritical and takes itself more seriously than it deserves. Accusing the enemy of dehumanizing the people you fight for (mass graves) within the game, but as a game dehumanizing the enemies by turning them into soul-less and voice-less pop-up targets ... And hence it ruins the moral discussion it tries to create from the onset.

reviewText:
Homefront is a game which has a alternative new future setting you are a pilot by the name of Robert Jackson freed by the resistance to help against the uprise of the the oppressive Unified Korea .

The story is with out a doubt amazing where North Korea occupies South Korea creating the Unified Korea and then goes to conquer the rest of Asia , there is tension between Iran and Saudi Arabia , and over Iraq but is only mensioned not shown in game , now due to Unified Korea occupied America and due to uprising againt your oppressors they kill more innocent people.

Now the gameplay is not absolutle new or innovative which makes it extremely generic , the guns have very few recoil which makes gun very easy to use hence nothing is challenging and weapons feel very similar none seem unique , health regenerates really fast making cover rarely usefuly as poping in and out of cover is enough to regenerate your health fully, besides that the campaign is only 4 hours long .

But the thing that makes the game very boring is how scripted the events are and how there is only one way to do things and its how the game makes it ,and how the pacing of the game is really off and you'll never feel any type of immersion or emotions off the game , the game's way of present the story is really bad that you don't care about any of the main characters and suprisingly none of them care about you the ending is very bad which makes it very clear they wanted a sequel, another thing is how bad the game makes use of friendly A.I. how you must always walk behind them so they open door , or climb ladder is just a waste of time.

The multiplayer has a few innovation in their introduction of battlepoints a currency used to purchase vehicles or equipements is a good concept but poorly executed because when you have a few enemy helicopter on top of your spawn it just fustrating to the people spawning as they will die instantly and have no chance to destroy air support till the round or end game ends and due to the low recoil weapons long ranged combat easy and, how some maps dont have enough cover which make sniper very prevelent.

In the end the Homefront is a game which doesn't have enough innovation to diffrentiate it from others from the genre , the story is great but the the way it is presented makes an under-par game.

reviewText: No meio de um mercado dominado por COD e Battlefield, que competem pra ver quem consegue atrair mais pseudo-gamers trouxas o bastante pra pagar 60 dólares por um jogo repetitivo e sem cérebro, além de torrar fortunas em DLCs ridículos, HOMEFRONT merecia um pouco mais de atenção. Seu modo multiplayer está praticamente morto (a developer fechou 3 meses após o lançamento), mas o singleplayer é fácil uma das melhores campanhas de um FPS que eu já joguei, mesmo sendo um pouco curta. Consegue realmente mexer com a cabeça do jogador, exibindo cenas fortes e bem polêmicas, mesmo pra um videogame. Se você não tiver nada melhor pra jogar, vale a pena, sem dúvida.

reviewText:
Don't waste your money.  The controls are janky, the graphics feel old and outdated.  The A.I. is terrible.  The plot is non-existant.  I played each one of the multiplayer map types, and they are bad as well.  It would have been a good game back in 2001.

The game has no depth and **spoiler alert** the last battle acros the Golden Gate Bridge is horrible, very Serious Sam type feeling.  If you are going to include landmarks in the game, at least build them accurately, including the land around it.

Also, the 60's music when you are riding in helicopters is completely played out in video games; to which this one has, with absolutely no reason to be included in the plot line other than a vietnam-era feel when you are flying.

1/5

reviewText: Not the best shooter out there, but if you like atmospheric shooters, it can still be very fun.  Although the missions are set on a pre-determined path, I thought they were pretty well executed (the last two missions were especially great). The campaign was challenging enough and short and sweet (7 missions, I finished in about 6 hours). The story is nothing to write home about but at least it was kind of new and original, and for the most part pretty immersive. There's also a multiplayer I haven't messed with too much, because as you would expect from a game this old, it's not very active. If you can pick it up  for less than $5, I'd suggest doing so.

reviewText:
Can't decide what to play?  Just start playing Homefront while you think about it.  By the time you decide, the game will be over.  I beat it in 5 hours but I also took some time to look for some of the extras, so yeah, it's that short.
This doesn't necessarily mean it's all bad.  It's got a fairly memorable campaign with quick fighting and some challenging moments.  The graphics are great, the shooting is tight.
As for the story, I'm a little torn.  On one hand, the concept of an occupied America makes the environment engrossing, so the story pulls you in more than, say, most Call of Duty games.  On the other hand the action in some areas is too ridiculous to be taken seriously, counteracting the attempt at an emotional campaign.  And considering you play a freedom fighter with supposed limited resources, guns are f***ing everywhere!  I don't think I ever had less than half ammo in any gun before I was able to grab another and everywhere I stepped I was picking up more grenades.  With all the sh** the Koreans leave lying around, how is it the Americans haven't wiped them out ages ago?
Anyways, I got it for like a 1.25, so I can't complain.  Fun, short little romp.  Recommended?  Meh.  Sure as hell not for 20.00.

reviewText:
I was really looking forward to Homefront when it was announced back in the day, and I pre-ordered it almost as soon as I could.
BUT, when the game was finally released.... It was a disappointment.. The story had so much potential, but the game didn't fully use it. Add to that, that the game was way too short, filled with bugs and ended up being a point-and-click-run-in-a-straight-line kinda game, made me feel like it was a waste of money..
What people mostly buy this game for nowadays, is for the multiplayer part, but honestly I felt like it was just a copy of all other multiplayer shooters on the marked and it didn't bring anything new, so a disappointment there as well.
I havn't tried it for years, but I doubt that it have been improved much since then..
You might disagree with me, but I was way too disappointed to give this game any recommendations and I told everybody I know to stay away from it, and those whom I know had bought it, sadly agrees with me.

reviewText:
This is quite a nice game, if you vave ever played Frontlines: Fuel of War then you would love this game

Homefront's multiplayer, seems primed to be just another also-ran right from the get-go. With only two core game modes (Team Deathmatch and Capture and Hold) playable in two variations, the options are few. The loadout screen will be instantly familiar to anyone who has played a Call of Duty game in the past few years, and the online conflicts play out between the KPA and the US Army (rather than the ragtag freedom fighters from the campaign), so the intriguing setting is little more than window dressing. Though its inspirations are obvious, Homefront does a good job of appropriating tried-and-true mechanics. Earning experience, leveling up, increasing your arsenal, and unlocking new infantry abilities (read: perks) is satisfying, and the maps allow a decent range of viable battlefield strategies.

Player base is a bit unfrendly for new players to join and enjoy, you need to get use to the fast run & gun style, Get ready to die alot

reviewText: There was a lot of hype associated with this game. The trailers alone were enough to convince a lot of people, including myself, to buy it. After completing it, I can't help but agree with the common criticism that the game is far too short. It'd be one thing if the ending brought some closure to the story, but it ends just as the action in the game gets really good, and in an obvious [failed] attempt to lure customers into eagerly anticipating the sequel. Given the alarmingly short campaign and the overestimated graphics, this game falls short of being worth its $49.99 price tag. The campaign is fun however, and the multiplayer, despite its relatively gutted graphics, has some potential for addictive and competitive gaming (especially for snipers), but it doesn't compete well with some other multiplayer FPS games available. While I don't feel completely disappointed, I can't in good conscience recommend it at its current price.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Unfortunately where Homefront had tremendous potential it completely dropped the ball in virtually every other. I really liked the story, especially since I'm from the San Francisco Bay Area where some of the story takes place, but that's where my positive thoughts for Homefront stops. How companies get away with only providing 4 hours of content now is beyond my understanding. The controls are clunky and you have to repeatedly press buttons to crouch and prone instead of holding them like I am used to. The mechanics are extremely unrefined - you can blast enemies in the head repeatedly and they won't die. You can barely peak out from a corner and an enemy far away can pick you off. The game feels too rushed and unpolished, and if they had taken the time to iron out everything and make the campaign longer, Homefront could have been a really good game.\n\nBut I do feel like the potential is there especially with it's great concept of a story - perhaps if Homefront 2 ever see's light, it will be refined and polished and provide us with more substance to allow us to really get into the game.

reviewText:
A bit graphics-intensive for my 4 years-old machine, however works pretty well once you bring down the motion blur and ambiant occlusion.
This said, I was disappointed by the length of the single-player campaign. A mere 4 hours for a crappy player like me is kind of pathetic. I died a few times, sure, but 4 hours of single-player isn't that great, despite the incredible story.
Because that's the main appeal; the main storyline is very gritty and harsh, loved it.

Multiplayer is a tad on the weak side, too. No co-op that I could find, which is a real shame. Playing this 2 players would be quite awesome. 4 would be even more incredible. It has a huge potential for great co-op gameplay, which is a shame it wasn't included.
As for the online multiplayer, it's somewhat of a slightly dumbed-down version of the Battlefield series.  It feels more like a giant free-for-all than an actual team-oriented multiplayer game. However, playing as a team will yield a much better experience overall.

There were elements of the game which tried very very hard to tug at your heartstrings, but in the end, just kind of got swept under by lack of emotional development.\n\nAnother yawner FPS.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Not a cutting edge shooter, but certainly not the worst game ever.
No one is ever too concerned about storylines these days, the pretence to this one was unique, but it just felt like a generic America vs Baddies game.

In terms of gameplay, unless your favourite weapon is an LMG, or an enemy weapon, you are out of luck, and will run out of ammo every few minutes and have to switch to a pick up SMG. This is one thing that annoyed me most, not being able to replenish assault rifle ammo with another type of assault rifle!

Enemies only seem to target you, they are surprisingly accurate too... hitting you 90% of the time, also, every time you pop your head up you will get splashed, and even when behind cover you will get hit - when crouched even if you can't see enemies over cover, they will often be able to hit you -  probably your forehead up sticks out over cover :(
Enemies drop grenades beside you with pin point accuracy too, meaning you have to run out of cover into the hail of bullets aimed directly at you

Obstacles nearly always come in the form of fridges or wardrobes, everytime you go to the next phase of a mission, it will be the main guy Connor (who orders you about the whole way) that pushes the fridge over, and you can continue your adventure. Clipping is also pretty annoying, before you hook up with the military, you have at least 2 people with you throughout, often 3, they will push you out of the way between firefights when you need to climb a ladder, go through a revolving door, etc, you are always last and it is annoying beyond belief! You don't actually get the option to go up/through until they have all passed.

All that aside, I enjoyed playing through the Campaign, although it was pretty short, and ended abruptly, I don't think at the end you have really accomplished anything at all. Steam says my time played was 3 hours, I'm pretty sure the multiplayer is permanently offline too. So definitely not worth paying full price for.

Summary: you run out of ammo quickly, seems like you are the only target for enemies, poor ending, multiplayer nonexistant

reviewText:
Homefront is a game with a wonderfully executed story, but it does have some annoying quirks in its gameplay.

For one, the game felt like another generic shooter, with no real unique twist. The Goliath system could be called one, but I personally found it annoying to have to switch back to it every time I wanted to fire (this was because once you fire with it you automatically put the targeter away). Some levels, especially the early missions, had portions where there was either too much cover, which essentially forced close quarters combat with long range rifles, and areas with too little cover, which stopped me from progressing as I had to find a place to go prone, get up, fire a few rounds, take enough rounds to almost die from enemies I couldn't see, and then go prone for my health to regenerate.

The controls also left a bit to be wanted as well. I was suprised to see that aim-down-sight is locked to toggle only, and can't be changed to hold to aim-down-sight. The helicopter controls were extremely dumbed down (even on the highest difficulty control level) and there were so many controls for the helicopter that were just completely un-realistic (i.e. you can pitch straight down or straight up and not gain/lose velocity and rolling the helicopter didn't actually give sideways velocity).

The weapons in the game also were a bit of a bad point for me because, other than a sniper rifle and a rocket launcher, they all felt the same. The shotgun was completely useless for the CQC areas that you get it for because the enemies are always too far away to hit without getting gunned down. The assault rifles and the LMG all felt the same and none had a specific scenario where it would be better than the other (I generally found myself using either the LMG or the Scar LMG since it had the most ammo and biggest clip), with the only diference being some rifles were full-auto, some were burst fire, and some were semi-auto. I also found the movement speed reduction while aiming was a bit annoying, and only really see it making sense with the LMG or the RPG.

The AI is also kind of strange. Hostile AI can sometimes hit you even if you are behind cover, and they really only target you, the player, with your AI allies taking fire rarely. Speaking of the AI allies, they are all but useless. When they aren't sitting crouched behind cover for entire firefights, they will randomly fire, sometimes in the direction of hostiles. I found that the allies worked best as spotters since they had a habit of firing at walls that hostiles were taking cover behind, and they don't stop firing at the one specific enemy they are targeting until it is killed, usually by the player.

The game's story was a great one though, and I really enjoyed the dark turns the game took in the labor camp levels, I just wish the game would have spent more time showing the Korean oppression. The story alone is the main reason I recommend this game, with its gameplay only being on par with other first person shooters of its time.

reviewText: Homefront's kind of... well, mediocre. The campaign is only four hours long and the multiplayer is a poor man's Battlefield clone. I did find myself moved at certain points in the campaign, but that seems to have been the idea- the man behind Red Dawn wanted to scare the pants off of people by making them think an invasion by North Korea was not only possible, but a very credible threat, and depict what would happen as a result. It's an engaging story, but it kind of falls apart when you stop and think about it long enough. Plus, heart-wrenching though some scenes were, they feel like cheap attempts to elicit tears in the end. Maybe that's the real horror of it, and this game is just about shock value. I dunno. It was if nothing else a competent single-player FPS with some good wow moments from the helicopter level and the guilty pleasure that is Goliath, autonomous ♥♥♥♥-wrecking attack drone.

reviewText:
Score -> 6/10

Homefront got a lot of mixed hits when it released and for a while afterwords. I picked it up on a Steam sale a couple summers ago. Havent played Multiplayer, I dont know if mp still exists, meaning if people still play it. As for single player, its story is very reminiscent of the Red Dawn movies (even has references in game towards those movies, specifically the original).

Story wise was good overall and cliche at times.

Combat and Manuverability was mostly good. There were a few instances where I personally thought it was a pain in the rear shooting at enemies while you have artillery canons firing next to you. You get screen shocks and your character aiming bouncing around because of it. Its realistic i guess so its not a huge problem. My big issue I noticed with combat, specifically when shoot at enemies is noticably you tend to shoot blanks from time to time. I know sounds liek a personal problem, it may as well be.

The save system or lack there of is kind of annoying a certain points of the game, its a check-point save system.

Oh the Single Player Campaign is VERY LINEAR. Not an issue if you like your classic FPS titles.

Lastly I played it on Guerilla (Hardest Difficulty) on first play through. It is at most a 5 hour game. I cant imagine how Easy would be. *shank... Shank... SHANK SHANK SHANK*

reviewText: Not the best shooter out there, but if you like atmospheric shooters, it can still be very fun.  Although the missions are set on a pre-determined path, I thought they were pretty well executed (the last two missions were especially great). The campaign was challenging enough and short and sweet (7 missions, I finished in about 6 hours). The story is nothing to write home about but at least it was kind of new and original, and for the most part pretty immersive. There's also a multiplayer I haven't messed with too much, because as you would expect from a game this old, it's not very active. If you can pick it up  for less than $5, I'd suggest doing so.
